name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is, for joint discussion, - the recommendation by Charles Tannock, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Partnership Agreement on relations and cooperationbetween the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and New Zealand, on the other (15470/2016 - C8-0027 / 2017 - 2016/0366 (NLE)) (A8-0327 / 2017), and -the report by Charles Tannock, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, with a non-legislative motion for a resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion on behalf of the Union of the Partnership Agreement on relations and cooperation between the European Unionand its Member States, on the one hand, and New Zealand, on the other (2017/2050 (INI) (A8-0333 / 2017).

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation, otherwise known as PARC, between the European Union and New Zealand is a much welcomed initiative. New Zealand is one of the EU’s closest partners, a country with which we share common values and interests. PARC builds on the existing joint declaration signed in 2007 developing and cementing those links, allowing for closer cooperation and more regular ministerial dialogue. I am pleased as rapporteur that we have been able to include a resolution alongside our consent motion, which allows us the opportunity to reaffirm our support for the agreement and to express our strong solidarity with New Zealand as a country. PARC covers many of the areas that we would expect to see, and is similar in scope to the recently signed Strategic Partnership Agreement with Canada, for which I am pleased to say I was also the rapporteur. These areas include fighting terrorism and organised crime, aiding global development, working together at the multilateral level, and combating climate change and supporting sustainable development. New Zealand is a leader in the renewable energy sector and has set itself ambitious targets for renewable energy production. This emphasis on combating climate change, supporting sustainable development and protecting biodiversity is very clear throughout the PARC, and I strongly support this. Article 15 for instance, which focuses on working together to further the WTO Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary measures, gives a sense of the level of commitment by all parties pledged to the specific regard here. We also see PARC reaffirming the terms of the Framework Participation Agreement (FPA) signed in 2012 which allows for New Zealand to contribute militarily towards European Union Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions. New Zealand, as our resolution notes, plays an important role in contributing towards peace and international security, a role that is all the more impressive when considering its relatively small size and geographical location. Its contribution, following the FPA, to the EU’s highly successful EU NAVFOR Atlanta, which was commanded from my own constituency in London, has been well received and we look forward to setting and seeing more cooperation of this kind in future. I should also mention again, highlighted in the resolution, the role that New Zealand has played in the European Union’s policing mission in Afghanistan. Indeed, it was at the sidelines of a Brussels meeting concerning Afghanistan that the PARC agreement was signed back in October of last year 2016. Looking at the resolution itself, I believe that I am speaking for the majority of this House, when I say that the positive tone taken reflects the extremely good will towards New Zealand felt by this Parliament and the belief that the relationship between the European Union, its Member States and New Zealand is a force for good in the world. To conclude, I believe that the signing of PARC is not only a positive development in ties between the New Zealand authorities and Government, and the European Union, but it is part of a wider development and success story of the EU itself, where we see it working effectively to secure agreements with third countries, both in terms of political cooperation, but also for trade. Having seen the passing of the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) and the Strategic Partnership Agreement (SPA) with Canada, this agreement with New Zealand marks the start of an increased engagement with the Pacific region, as the European Union is set to start trade negotiations with New Zealand shortly. It is also doing so with Australia and Japan in the next year or so. I believe that this will send a strong signal to all of those that doubt and seek to undermine the achievements and benefits of European Union membership. This morning’s debate is a chance for this Parliament to demonstrate the strong support for New Zealand that exists across the entire political spectrum, as was illustrated only too clearly by the overwhelming vote in favour of these motions in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Therefore, I look forward to hearing the rest of the debate.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity of this debate on the European Union-New Zealand Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation. In the first place, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for his excellent report and for his engagement throughout the process in Parliament. I believe this report gives an excellent overview of the relationships and relations between the European Union and New Zealand, and is a very good background to inform today’s vote in this Parliament on consent to the conclusion of the agreement. As a general remark, let me say that the agreement is the outcome of our efforts to provide a modern framework for relations with one of the European Union’s closest partners in the Asia-Pacific region. European Union relations with New Zealand are excellent and I sincerely believe they will continue to develop under the new Government of Prime Minister Ardern. President Tusk has just had a first, very positive exchange of views with the Prime Minister at the East-Asia Summit. The European Union and New Zealand are like-minded partners, and consequently we coordinate closely on a number of international issues. We also have very good development cooperation, especially in the Pacific, which focuses mostly on clean energy and climate-change-related projects. In parallel, political dialogue with New Zealand has been intensifying and there has been an ever-increasing number of political contacts over the past years. In 2016, the European Union upgraded its diplomatic representation in New Zealand from chargé d’affaires to ambassador level. We highly appreciate our cooperation in crisis management. In the past, New Zealand participated in the European Union operations in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Afghanistan and the Horn of Africa. In 2012, the European Union and New Zealand signed a framework participation agreement, the first one of the Asia-Pacific region, which reinforced the EU-New Zealand broader partnership and opened new avenues for cooperation. Since 2014, a regular strategic security dialogue has been taking place at senior official level. Our partnership and cooperation agreement with New Zealand upgrades our relationship to make it fit for the 21st century. We share the same views on many global issues, and approach these issues in a similar way. We support democracy, the rule of law and human rights, and are active players in multilateral organisations such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organization. We also have shared interests in tackling key global challenges such as climate change, sustainable development and preserving the environment, in addition to humanitarian aid and the fight against terrorism, to name just these. As regards the economy, we have a shared interest in launching our free-trade agreement (FTA) and these negotiations should be launched as soon as possible. We already have dynamic economic relationships and we look forward to expanding our trade links further. Our successful preparatory work demonstrates that we see eye to eye on many issues, but let me assure the honourable Members that we have had the utmost regard to agricultural sensitivities. In November 2016 the Commission released a study on the cumulative impact of future trade agreements in the agricultural sector. The ruminant meat and dairy sectors were identified as more sensitive ones in a possible free-trade agreement with New Zealand. These sensitivities are fully reflected in the European Union’s trade negotiation strategy for the free-trade agreement. The draft directives for negotiating the FTA were published by the Commission in September this year and the discussions in the Council are ongoing. Parliament has fed into these discussions with a dedicated report which was adopted at the end of October.  I trust that the Council will adopt the negotiating directives soon, which will enable the Commission to launch the FTA negotiations at the beginning of 2018. The Commission looks forward to continuing cooperation with Parliament on this matter.

name: Traian Ungureanu
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, in a world full of confusion and contradictions, we can count on little certainty. New Zealand is one of them. We are rightly talking about New Zealand as a friend with whom we share the same values, even if geographically speaking, a world separates us. It is normal for all these things to materialize in a political, economic and technological partnership. Moreover, this convergence was directly reflected in the excellent collaboration of political groups during the debates on this report. And I would especially like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Charles Tannock, on the tact and flexibility with which he led this report. The EU-New Zealand Relations and Cooperation Partnership Agreement, which we will vote on today, and the accompanying resolution, can and must pave the way for the negotiation of an EU-New Zealand free trade agreement. According to the Commission's intentions, these negotiations will start before the end of the year. It is true that, more recently, the popularity of free trade agreements is not very high, but the advantages and opportunities that free trade agreements open up cannot be denied either statistically or rationally.

name: Andi Cristea
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Charles Tannock, and our colleagues in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), for the very strong and comprehensive text submitted before this House today. Parliament values very much the partnership with New Zealand, and we look forward to an even more ambitious cooperation. This is the spirit of the report and our contribution. The EU and New Zealand are like-minded partners, with common values and interests. The Partnership Agreement will foster an even more effective bilateral engagement by strengthening political dialogue and improving cooperation in a wide range of areas.  New Zealand is one of the EU’s closest friends and valued allies. At a time of high international volatility, where mistrust and populists risk undermining multilateralism and the interest of the international community at large, the EU is proud to forge and foster even closer alliances with like-minded nations and long-standing partners like New Zealand. The Partnership Agreement will provide a forward-looking political framework within which EU-New Zealand relations and cooperation on sustainable development and a comprehensive range of issues will be developed even further for years to come, in order to match new ambitions and aspirations.  I am confident that today’s vote will confirm with a large consensus a strong and substantive text and will reiterate and underline once again the energy and ambition of this longstanding relationship, of which the Partnership Agreement will now be the most eloquent pillar. Many thanks to the rapporteur and colleagues, once again, for their cooperation and support.

name: David Campbell Bannerman
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, while recently in New Zealand for my work on the parallel EU-New Zealand Free Trade Agreement, I was reminded of the importance of the deep and special relationship with our Kiwi friends. The EU is New Zealand’s third-largest trading partner, after Australia and China, whilst the UK remains New Zealand’s top EU export destination. EU Member States and New Zealand enjoy a strong partnership, sharing many common goals, with strong political, economic and cultural ties, including in multilateral organisations such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organisation.  The recently signed EU-New Zealand Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation (called PARC for short) is an important tool in modernising these historic links. This is a parallel, but separate, agreement covering non-trade aspects, very similar to Canada’s Strategic Partnership Agreement and Australia’s Framework Agreement. It aims to facilitate more effective bilateral engagement by strengthening political dialogue on a wide range of issues, from customs to innovation, education and culture, to migration, judicial affairs and the fight against global terrorism and cybercrime.  I expect a similar strategic agreement between the EU and the UK post-Brexit. I give credit to my friend and colleague Charles Tannock for his work in steering the PARC report through the European Parliament, and not leaving it parked.

name: Norica Nicolai
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, although geographically remote, New Zealand is very close in terms of sharing democratic values ​​and high civil standards with the European Union. This explains the fact that for us, but certainly also for New Zealand, this agreement will be a step towards enhanced cooperation. We have a long tradition of economic collaboration. Of course, we are the third partner in trade relations, the first being the United Kingdom, and, I hope that in the future, after we have a free trade agreement, continental Europe will be a much more influential and much stronger partner in this relationship. We have a long history of security cooperation, not only Bosnia and Herzegovina, but other peacekeeping missions have found us together. We have a strengthened and effective partnership in the fight against terrorism and beyond. Climate change, which concerns us all, is also a level of cooperation between the European Union and Australia. That is why this agreement, in our opinion, will be significant and will mark a new vision regarding the vocation of the global player of the European Union. I want to thank Mr. Tannock for his cooperation. I believe that few reports have had such enhanced cooperation between political groups, not only because the report reflects our choice of cooperation agreements, but also because New Zealand is one of the most deserving partners in our external relations. all areas of activity.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, in the eyes of many people in Europe, New Zealand is a bit of a fairytale country on the other side of the world. Relatively sparse population, large areas of beautiful nature together with the location of one of the last embankments on the way to Antarctica and the South Pacific make this country a potential paradise for tourists and researchers. It is interesting that in January 2017, immediately after the start of the Brexit negotiations, the Prime Minister of this country directed his first foreign trip to the European Parliament, London and Berlin. In doing so, he made it clear that, in addition to traditional relations with London, the country was interested in special relations with the European Union. It should be noted that the author of the report mistakenly mixes the European Union and Europe. Which is not so surprising for the British MP Tannock. The negotiation of a free trade agreement with New Zealand will certainly be a delicate and sensitive issue, especially for agricultural products. It will be interesting for EU countries to use New Zealand's experience with environmental protection and stabilization of electricity supply in conditions where more than 80% of production comes from renewable sources. We do not yet know this in the European Union. The country's involvement in the International Fund for Ireland is interesting. This fund supports the economic and social development of Green Island and contributes to dialogue and community reconciliation. By the way, the issue of Ireland is one of the first points of Commissioner Barnier's talks with representatives of the British Government.

name: Jordi Solé
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we support closer relations between the European Union and New Zealand and therefore we welcome the conclusion of the Partnership Agreement with a country that, although far away from us geographically speaking, is very close and like-minded when it comes to standards of democracy, human rights, fundamental freedoms, international law, and so on. A country with one of the highest Human Development Index rankings, there are many things from New Zealand to praise, for instance the functioning of its institutions of government, the way minorities are nowadays respected and promoted, its relevant commitment to sustainable development and to peacekeeping operations, and its valuable efforts in the fight against climate change, with more than 80% of its electricity coming from renewable energy sources. It also seems to me remarkable that, since some weeks ago, New Zealand, the first country in the world in which all women had the right to vote, has now the world’s youngest female head of government, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern. We believe that this Partnership Agreement can provide for a framework that promotes and further develops the relationship with a country with which we can work together for a better advanced and future-oriented governance. We also hope that this instrument can bring about more people-to-people ties, the ties that make countries and regions really come closer, and that it will also be useful to deepen relations between the EU and the Asia-Pacific region.  When it comes to negotiations for a new Free Trade Agreement, our position is much less enthusiastic, first and foremost because we favour a multilateral trade agenda and multilateral negotiations to regulate world trade, where respect for human rights, the environment and social rights prevail. Secondly, we want clear limits for negotiations, especially with regard to agriculturally-sensitive issues, animal welfare, a phasing out of extensive agricultural production methods, or the possibility of sustainable development chapters. Thirdly, we call for a bigger democratic oversight for all trade negotiations. Thus, we would have preferred that the resolution simply took note of, instead of openly supporting, the launch of the Free Trade Agreement negotiations. Notwithstanding our position on the FTA, we welcome this PARC, insofar as it will allow us to have stronger ties with New Zealand, and we thank the rapporteur, Mr Tannock, for his work.

name: Patrick O’Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it seems to me that the prospect of Brexit is spurring EU interest in warming up relations, and indeed trading ties, with many of the countries eager to reach trade deals with the United Kingdom after its departure. It is widely regarded as a source of shame in Britain that in the 1970s our country threw up tariff barriers against our historic Commonwealth friends such as Australia and New Zealand. That is a wrong which is soon to be righted, as the United Kingdom broadens its economic and diplomatic relationships across the world, raising the priority we give to Commonwealth nations, as well as seeking to sustain links with Member States of the European Union. New Zealand is a magnificent country, a bedrock of democratic values in its region and a key part of the Anglosphere, so it is good to see the EU strengthening political relationships with New Zealand as well. As regards the agricultural sector, New Zealand farmers are renowned the world over for their enterprising attitudes and ability to get by without any subsidies, let alone expensive and extensive networks such as those contained in the EU common agricultural policy. It is good also to hear Mr Hogan talking specifically about free-trade agreements with New Zealand – not before time, many will think – albeit not as part of the arrangements under the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation. I believe that the United Kingdom’s International Trade Secretary, Liam Fox, may be a few steps ahead of the EU in this regard. If, indeed, the prospect of Brexit is serving as a catalyst for the EU to reduce its tariff walls against the ‘sunrise’ parts of the global economy, then that is yet another benefit of the United Kingdom’s magnificent decision to rejoin the global family of independent sovereign nations.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have nothing against New Zealand. What strikes me about this text, the text of its rapporteur, is the religious relationship with free trade. Neither the failure of NAFTA, nor the US withdrawal from TAFTA, nor our public opposition to CETA deters you from continuing down this path. The threats weighing on our agriculture, and especially on the livestock sectors, delivered to the intensive New Zealand agribusiness, are deliberately ignored. By the unlimited and unconditional extension of free trade, you prevent our states and parliaments from protecting the food security and independence of the peoples of Europe, as well as ensuring the survival of our economies. The European Union's march towards borderlessness destroys the very reason for Europe, because it shows your search for a world government. We must leave these deadly European institutions if we want to save the European project.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the European Union's partnership with New Zealand includes a wide range of activities, including trade. New Zealand has as its second export destination the European Union, from which it imports mainly industrial products, cars, machinery, television equipment but also clothing and textiles. Because New Zealand mainly imports mutton, wool, fruit, wine and dairy products, which are also produced in the countries of southern Europe, trade in these products must be done with special care. In fact, given that the partnership provides for customs cooperation and the removal of some technical barriers, including customs duties, trade defense must be activated, as there is a risk that products will come from New Zealand. create conditions of unfair competition with the corresponding products of the European South, which is unacceptable and should not happen.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Next year we will celebrate the centenary of the end of World War I. On the occasion of today's debate, it is worth emphasizing that New Zealand - this small country, then less than a million - put 100,000 of its soldiers on the side of the Allies, helping us to win. It was no worse during World War II. Two hundred thousand New Zealanders fought on the good side of the force. It is not surprising, then, that we are also connected by formal relations, such as the joint declaration on relations and cooperation of 2007 or the partnership agreement for relations and cooperation of October 5, 2016. One might even be surprised that it was only so late that we signed such an important us binding contracts. Because what connects us? Cultural ties, political ties, economic ties, respect for human rights and the rule of law, cooperation in the field of environment and security, including the fight against terrorism. So I am glad that the result of all this will - I hope as soon as possible - the conclusion of a free trade agreement between us. It is worth recalling that the European Union is the third trade partner for New Zealand, and the value of our common economic exchange is around 20 billion New Zealand dollars. The European Union is also the second investor in New Zealand. Importantly, New Zealand is a democratic state that respects the rule of law, environmental protection and minority rights. Nothing separates us except distance, therefore let us continue to build this cooperation between us.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur. The European Parliament's recommendation to conclude a partnership agreement with New Zealand could only be positive. New Zealand, it was recalled, is in fact one of the countries closest to us, as it shares the same democratic values ​​and principles, respect for human rights, fundamental issues such as peace, security and the environment. A common culture, therefore, and sensitivity that has made it possible to establish a close partnership with the European Union and with the Member States, which has resulted in common political choices. I refer to New Zealand's contribution to UN peacekeeping operations in Bosnia, Kosovo, Sierra Leone and Afghanistan, to the training of Iraqi security forces fighting Daesh, to the role of co-sponsor of the UN Security Council resolutions in Syria and the peace process. in the Middle East. Furthermore, its important role as a contributor and provider of assistance to sustainable development and poverty reduction in developing countries, to the concrete commitment to climate matters under the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, and to the implementation of Paris Agreement, as part of COP21. It is therefore good to have reached the conclusion of this agreement, which also includes the fight against terrorism, in particular commitments on the exchange of information on terrorist networks and groups, on methods to prevent, counter and combat terrorism, radicalization and cybercrime. , but also intended for scientific, academic and technological cooperation. A choice consistent with the start of negotiations on the free trade agreement between the EU and New Zealand, which must take place in a spirit of reciprocity and mutual benefit, taking into account the sensitivity of some agricultural and other products. An important agreement, a coherent future-oriented political framework within which relations and cooperation on a wide range of issues will be further developed over the years, in the interest of the citizens of the Union and New Zealand.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: - Mr President, as a member of the Australia-New Zealand Group, I clearly welcome the Free Trade Agreement with New Zealand. It is precisely barrier-free trade that is the best way to deepen relations between the countries of the world, especially those with which we have strong political, historical and cultural ties, and New Zealand is such a country. As a member of the Australia-New Zealand parliamentary group, I have met a number of relevant players and I can say that this agreement should have been concluded a long time ago. According to my information, it was mainly hampered by the fears of Western European farmers about New Zealand beef. I consider this a joke, as New Zealand farmers do not receive any subsidies at all and, in addition, they have to transport their products across Europe to Europe. Fearing such competition is a very weak business card for Western European farmers. I therefore want to express the hope that, following today's approval of the PARC cooperation agreement, a free trade agreement will soon be concluded.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL).
text: - Of course there is nothing wrong with good relations with New Zealand. It is a beautiful country, with beautiful people and wonderful ideas. But I would like to work with New Zealand in a way that is truly in the service of sustainability, climate and workers' rights. This partnership agreement is a first step towards yet another free trade agreement. That means more trade, more transport, more fuel costs and more emissions. That doesn't serve the climate at all. The climate conference in Bonn teaches us that we are not even getting close to the goals we set ourselves in Paris. The intention to go further in these agreements with Australia and New Zealand than already intended in the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) also threatens the labor rights and job security of European workers. And what do all these combined free trade agreements mean for the agricultural sector? Can the Commissioner clarify this? The trade agreements concluded by the European Union are based on a convergence of regulations. That means that we lose control over our rules. This is done through explicit agreements on this, but also through a much more invisible working method, namely by the regulatory cooperation body. This makes it invisible and uncontrollable for a representative of the people exactly how our rules converge. The fact that New Zealand has just agreed to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) doesn't make things any better. There are big differences between the rules all over the world and the countries of Europe are quite lonely at the top. If we start to converge with the whole world, we are pretty sure that we will lose our standards. I have nothing against New Zealand, but I have against these kinds of trade agreements. You should not make agreements like this with your friends. Thank you.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - It is great that relations with New Zealand are developing successfully.We recognize the same values and closer economic relations will certainly contribute to the strengthening of the international value community.On the other hand, things are not as simple as they seem at first glance.First of all, we must not forget that by creating bilateral special trade agreements, we are together destroying international structures.The hard-established World Trade Organization stays on the sidelines.Third parties also see the message that short-term benefits may be sought.Are we thinking about the long-term prospects for such activities?Nor can we ignore the ecological impact.I will not repeat the statistics on the impact of climate change on the New Zealand livestock sector alone.Do we really want to promote it even more while accelerating climate change?

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! About six weeks ago, I had the pleasure of welcoming, on behalf of President Tajani, a group of Members of the New Zealand Parliament, headed by President Carter. It was an opportunity to make such a short review and compare at the same time intentions, will, similarities and differences. Well, the first general observation: historically we are close to each other, that is, Europe is close to New Zealand. The second thing is very important: our economies are not competitive, our economies are largely complementary. Third observation: the size of the European Union in every respect and the size of New Zealand are two completely different sizes. And finally, what they are very interested in is honest cooperation and the question: how will we divide, especially the trade in agricultural products, after Brexit. The second - cooperation in the field of terrorism and combating terrorism. As a general observation - congratulations on considering this report. I highly recommend support.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation between the European Union and New Zealand and I want to congratulate Mr Tannock on a very good report. We already enjoy strong relations and share many common goals on international issues. There are many deep historical ties between Northern Ireland, which I represent, and New Zealand. William Massey, the 19th Prime Minister of New Zealand, grew up in Limavady, in County Londonderry, so there is a great tie between my region and New Zealand. It is vital that we build on these ties with New Zealand and other Commonwealth countries, while we are in the European Union and also once we leave. It is clear that there is political will from both the Commission and New Zealand to get the ball rolling on a free-trade agreement. As rapporteur, for the Agriculture Committee, on trade with New Zealand, I firmly believe that this has the potential to provide opportunities for our producers if a fair and balanced trade deal can be achieved. And that is the bottom line here. Commissioner, you will be going off to Buenos Aires very shortly, for the World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference, and it will be linked to that as well. We in Europe have got to be positive on trade, because if we are negative it will work against us.  I heard comments earlier in this debate about Europe trying to outdo the UK. I have a feeling that, while Europe has left the starting post on this issue, Dr Fox is still in the paddock and has not even got on his horse yet. From my point of view, I think we are in a very interesting position, where Europe will go ahead, and the UK will have good trade. So we will have good relations with this brilliant – lovely – country and I wish it well, with every success in the future.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the conclusion of this partnership agreement with New Zealand and my congratulations too to Charles Tannock. In these times of increasing isolation and nationalism, I think it is of paramount importance that we join forces with partners who share our values and our world vision to advance an open rules-based global order that works for the people. As an MEP in the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats Group (S&D), I welcome that the recent elections in New Zealand resulted in a Labour-led government, championing an agenda of sustainable development.  Clearly, the EU and New Zealand are already finding an important common cause and we are making progress on trade negotiations on which this House adopted recommendations last month. Aside from trade, I hope this partnership will help us to focus our attention on a region of important mutual strategic benefit – the Asia-Pacific region. Whether it concerns the stability in the South China Sea that harbours vital shipping routes, combating climate change or addressing terrorist threats, this region is of key strategic importance to the European Union and I call upon the High Representative, the Council and the Commission to ensure that this agreement is a stepping stone to advancing our partnerships in the Asia-Pacific region, where New Zealand is an important actor.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, I support the Partnership Agreement on relations and cooperation between the European Union and New Zealand because it is our close partner when it comes to defending democratic principles and human rights. The first permanent ambassador of the European Union to New Zealand took office last year, opening an autonomous delegation of the European Union to New Zealand. New Zealand is committed to participating in European Union crisis management operations: the EUNAVFOR Atalanta around the Horn of Africa, the EUPOL mission in Afghanistan and the EUFOR mission (Althea) in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I emphasize the importance of enhanced care for the environment and the seas to protect natural resources, common goals in the fight against climate change and partnership in the field of universal access to sustainable energy, in line with the United Nations initiative of the same name. I believe in the partnership between the European Union and New Zealand because we share the same values ​​and interests. Our partnership needs to be upgraded with an economic dimension by concluding free trade agreements. I hope that we will overcome the differences in terms of recognition of geographical indications of products.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur on the excellent work carried out and stressing the importance of this partnership agreement with New Zealand. New Zealand is one of the countries in the world with which we have the closest proximity, it is a democratic rule of law that has an interpretation of international issues very close to that prevailing within the European Union and, therefore, we have every reason to seek to strengthen political links with New Zealand. In this sense, this partnership agreement may inaugurate a new phase in this scope. But I also want to say that I hope that, in addition to this partnership agreement at the political level, and with what it entails in several dimensions that have already been mentioned, this is also an important step towards the full progress towards the conclusion of an agreement free trade agreement with Australia. I believe that the European Union cannot close in on itself, the European Union must also open up from the point of view of trade relations with other parts of the world and New Zealand is naturally, due to its cultural and political values ​​proximity , a trading partner to recommend to the European Union.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I too would like to start by congratulating Mr Tannock on his excellent report.I think it is very convenient for the European Parliament to approve the Association Agreement with New Zealand, a geographically distant country, but, as has already been said, very close to the European Union in values, principles and interests.And he is also clearly committed to international cooperation and governance.With the signing of the Framework Agreement with Australia last August, the European Union took another step in strengthening its presence in Asia-Pacific.I believe that the Union is a global player and it must continue to be so, too, when we become a Europe of 27 States.For this, we have to strengthen our projection in a region as broad but also as dynamic as the Asia-Pacific region, and the New Zealand agreements, and also the Australian one, will serve us well.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, New Zealand is linked to the European Union and its Member States by a close and long-standing partnership, and has already concluded bilateral free trade agreements with important countries such as Australia, Thailand and the China. New Zealand is a country with high standards of civilization that promotes sustainable production methods, particularly in the food sector, and has promoted global agreements on global climate and mitigation of emissions. However, we must not make mistakes already made in the past, because any free trade agreement involves some risk, especially for our agri-food production. The protection intended to be reserved for European agri-food products, which are sensitive products and which, for example, have already been put at risk by agreements such as CETA, must therefore be clarified as a matter of priority. New Zealand is an important partner. The free trade agreement may bring benefits to both countries, but Europe must be able to protect its assets and specificities with the utmost care.

name: Maria Heubuch (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! Nobody doubts here that we together really respect the values ​​on which we are based, and I too want to do that at this point. But are we really complementary economies, as was said before? I don't see it that way with every product in agriculture. And here is an overall problem. We do a lot of trade agreements - it was just called CETA - we're going to Mercosur, we're going to Australia, to New Zealand, now comes Japan. But who really looks at what that ultimately means for agriculture and food production? Who is really evaluating what is in store for us overall? We look at each agreement individually, but that adds up. I see a very big problem here. We have to evaluate exactly what it means here overall. Food is not a normal commodity, it is not a car that we can manufacture as we wish. Food production has a lot to do with the local regions, with the people who work there, and that also has to do with how we then deal with the environment. I think we should evaluate that better here and build more protection here.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the European Union's good political relations with New Zealand are being used as a political outlet, as an argument, simply to enter into a free trade agreement, as was the case with CETA. Those who support free trade are usually from the Nordic countries, which produce industrial products that they export to New Zealand. But there is a serious problem, Mr HOGAN, which has to do with agriculture: agricultural production in the European Union will be hit and there will be too many problems for livestock, with New Zealand dairy products and the food industry. We must not go back to a story like with CETA. There must be protection of products of designation of origin, protection of geographical indications, protection of feta and other products that are traditional for Greece. Let us not return to discuss what happened with the CETA case and Canada.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! In the Committee on Agriculture, we adopted an opinion on agriculture in the negotiation of a trade agreement with New Zealand. The author was Mr Nicholson, who spoke earlier, an excellent specialist in this relationship and in this agricultural sector. I want to say that New Zealand has a competitive agricultural sector with a strong export orientation dominated by the dairy, sheep, goat, beef and fruit sectors. The agricultural trade accounts for a large proportion of New Zealand's total trade. New Zealand is an exporter of mainly agricultural products, while the Union of processed products to New Zealand. We have problems with the difference in standards or geographical indications. We know New Zealand is an advocate of full trade liberalization. It is true that New Zealand is competitive with European agriculture, but that does not mean that we are not to develop trade. We have to negotiate appropriate conditions, partnership conditions, because trade is the basic factor of development and growth, and globalization on the world market is simply going in this direction. It should also be expected that New Zealand, which was part of the TPP, the Trans-Pacific Partnership, will probably return - there will be a reason - for these talks and the Trans-Pacific Partnership will gain new dimensions.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everybody for the very constructive exchanges in relation to this agreement, and to thank all who spoke on the subject. I greatly appreciate the discussion and your interest in the European Union-New Zealand Partnership Agreement on Relations and Cooperation. The debate has shown very strong support for the strengthening of the European Union and New Zealand relationship through this agreement and, although we are geographically far from one another, dialogue and cooperation between the EU and New Zealand have never been as close as they are today. This new agreement gives us the opportunity to consolidate our achievements and advance onto a range of issues relevant to the challenges of our time. Many Members have clearly expressed some concerns about the future negotiations in relation to a free-trade agreement. I can say that the Commission and the negotiating mandate in relation to these issues are fully transparent. The two negotiating directives and the mandate in relation to these negotiations are on our website, and the sensitivities in relation to agriculture will be included. The Commission has made it absolutely clear to our New Zealand counterparts that agricultural sensitivities must be taken into account and that no full liberalisation can be contemplated for some sectors.  The Commission has proposed in the draft negotiating directives, which have already highlighted the agricultural sensitivities, to ensure that any future agreement will not cause major disruption in the European Union, including in the outermost regions. The important thing is that our sensitivities on market access and geographical indications are acknowledged, and these are well known to New Zealand and are being acknowledged by it in the scoping process. In relation to specific issues of trade and agriculture, and trade generally, the broader geopolitical considerations are important for a like-minded partner in the Oceania-Pacific region. New Zealand, together with Australia, is among the fastest-growing developed economies. There will be gains for the cars and car parts, machinery, chemicals and services sectors. The agricultural sector, as well, will benefit from improved market access for processed products, for cheeses and alcoholic beverages – particularly important for the agricultural sector with the acknowledgment of our geographical indications (GI) scheme and the recognition of our GI products such as wines, spirits and agri-food products. New Zealand has recognised this at ministerial level and the scoping paper reflects the high level of ambition that we can pursue on geographical indications, which is providing a good starting point for the actual negotiations. Can I also say to Ms Heubuch that we will include, as we do in every free-trade negotiating mandate, issues around environment, issues around animal welfare, animal health, and indeed plant health. All of these issues will be very important in terms of pursuing an ambitious outcome, which will ultimately have to be approved by this House, in relation to whether we have achieved enough or not. Lastly, I would say to Mr O’Flynn that I look forward to meeting Secretary of State Fox in the marketplace, and he will see that size matters when it comes to trade in the European Union where we have 450 million customers, while he will have about 70 million customers. I hope that we will be able to continue the high standards for food that we have become accustomed to in free-trade agreements in the European Union, and we will not lower our standards to what has been advocated in the marketplace in the context of any free-trade agreement by Secretary Fox.

name: Charles Tannock
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, as we wind up the debate I would first like to thank the Commissioner and the shadow rapporteurs across Parliament who have all been very supportive throughout the process. The report’s passage through the committee stage and the Parliament has also been very smooth, and whilst this is largely due to the widespread support that exists for greater cooperation with New Zealand in everything from fighting terrorism to mitigating climate change, clearly it shows that New Zealand really is close to us in many ways.  As I set out in my earlier speech and has been echoed throughout the House, this agreement is welcome and therefore something we can be proud of. As a Brit, however, I have to admit that this is a bittersweet moment, given my country’s impending exit from the European Union. There are those in Britain, and in this House, sadly, that still believe in a British Empire Mk. II, and that the United Kingdom has been held back in freely trading and cooperating with its old Commonwealth partners such as Canada, Australia and New Zealand.  The truth is that Britain will now have to renegotiate from scratch, on a bilateral basis, political agreements such as this and future FTAs which, by the time of Brexit in 2019, will have already been concluded for the EU. This is a great pity for my country, and certainly can illustrate the increasing success that the European Union is achieving now in negotiating and signing ambitious political and free trade agreements with democratic countries and economic blocs in the Asia-Pacific region and in the wider globe.  As I conclude, my only final wish is to welcome this initiative and the eventual FTA and to hope that later today we will be able to celebrate its successful adoption by Parliament.

name: Presidente. –
text: The joint discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 16 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing.- The EU and New Zealand are like-minded countries with similar views on global issues, with a number of common goals.In order to better achieve common goals, it makes sense to increase cooperation and dialogue.The purpose of the EU-New Zealand Partnership and Cooperation Partnership Agreement is to strengthen the partnership, increase cooperation in various fields and enhance communication.This is the case, for example, in the field of foreign and security, such as weapons of mass destruction, the fight against terrorism and the promotion of peace and security in the world.The agreement also provides for increased cooperation in the economic, trade and scientific fields.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - New Zealand has been a partner for many years with the European Union and its members, with whom it shares common values, human rights, fundamental freedoms, the rule of law, peace and security. New Zealand, together with the USA, Canada and Australia, is a member of the "Five Eyes" community, which works closely with the "Fourteen Eyes" community, in which EU members also participate: France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Belgium, Sweden, Denmark and Spain. Also, New Zealand is a longtime member of the OECD, IMF, ADB and the newly formed AIIB. The European Union considers New Zealand the 3rd largest trading partner, which already has good cooperation with the European Union's closest partners such as the United States (agreement signed in 2010 by the Wellington Declaration) and Australia (1983 agreement). New Zealand has also concluded bilateral free trade with Australia, Singapore, Thailand, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Malaysia and South Korea, as well as multilateral trade agreements under the Trans-Pacific Strategic Economic Partnership Agreement with Singapore, Chile and Brunei. It is very important for the European Union to improve relations with New Zealand because of the sharing of common interests. Future cooperation would contribute to the development of both New Zealand and the members of the European Union.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. - Cooperation between the EU and New Zealand has a huge impact on the further development of these two economies and their mutual relations. The subject of the debate was the draft non-legislative resolution on a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of a partnership agreement on relations and cooperation between the European Union and New Zealand. On October 5, 2016, New Zealand and the EU signed a Partnership in Relations and Cooperation Agreement (PARC). This agreement testifies to an apparently close relationship between the two parties recently. Not only should it be noted the high level of mutual relations, but also the readiness for further cooperation in the near future. The agreement creates long-term cultural, political and economic ties between the EU and New Zealand, strengthens common values ​​for human rights and the rule of law, and provides for further cooperation in areas such as innovative technologies, environmental protection and security. PARC ensures full cooperation between the countries of the Community and New Zealand for the common good. Moreover, it not only strengthens political dialogue and economic cooperation, but also positively influences the development of science, education and culture. It should be added that such a partnership will contribute to a more effective fight against the problem of migration, terrorism, organized crime as well as cybercrime. Both parties support the agreement as much as possible and are willing to develop together. Therefore, it is very important to support the motion for a resolution on relations and cooperation between EU members and New Zealand.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on freedom of expression in Sudan, in particular the case of Mohamed Zine al-Abidine (2017/2961 (RSP)).

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Mr President, a free press is one of the essentials for ensuring that a meaningful democratic system can function operating under the rule of law. Without such an underpinning, other efforts and programmes aimed at improving good governance and development are always undermined. I am pleased that we are therefore taking the opportunity today to shine a spotlight on the terrible state of press freedom in Sudan, particularly illustrated by the case of journalist Mohamed Zine al-Abidine and his editor-in-chief Osman Mirgani. Al-Abidine, in a clear case of political persecution and selective justice, has been sentenced to a suspended sentence of five years, ostensibly for writing a piece alleging corruption associated with the ruling family of President Omar al-Bashir. Whilst this is a most egregious example, it is sadly not an isolated case. In 2016, there were 44 occurrences of confiscated publications affecting 12 different newspapers, which gives you an idea of the widespread nature of such repressive practices in Sudan. All of this is in clear contradiction of the Cotonou Agreement. I hope that today’s debate will serve as a call on the Commission to remind the Sudanese authorities of their obligations under international law.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: author. – Mr President, it is sad that today we are again discussing Sudan. Not only because nothing has changed but especially because the situation is getting even worse, mainly in regard to freedom of expression. Reporters Without Borders ranks Sudan among the least free countries, at 174 out of 180 in the 2017 World Press Freedom Index, due to the harassment of the media and confiscation of newspapers issue. In addition to this, a new concern arises in regard to the proposed Press and Printing Act of 2017, which includes further controversial restrictions to online publication and provisions for the lengthier suspension of newspapers and journalists. It is true that today the spotlights are on Mohamed Zine al-Abidine who is paying very dearly for the choice to have respected the fundamental right of freedom of expression. But let us not forget about all of those, also in Europe, who lost even their lives simply because they shed some light on unacceptable situations. Parliament just yesterday dedicated a room within these premises in honour of Daphne Caruana Galizia, the Maltese journalist brutally assassinated for speaking out the truth. Parliament and all its Members have to make a strong contribution so as to prevent such situations. This is why we will support this resolution by which we urge the Sudanese Government to stop its heinous practices against journalists and editors, in order to start to build a democratic environment where both the rule of law and human rights are respected. Unfortunately, this is just one aspect of a more complex picture that includes several violations of human rights, ranging from the well-known situation in Darfur to international criminal law concerns. I conclude by saying that, with great honour, I will take part next month in the Sub—committee on Human Rights’ mission to Sudan, so as hopefully to provide support, not only to Mr Mohamed Zine al-Abidine, but to all journalists who are victims of harassment, intimidation and attacks, and advocate freedom of online and offline expression.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Author. - Mister President! I welcome the fact that we are appealing to the Sudanese government to respect civil liberties. Again and again newspapers are confiscated by the all-powerful secret service and the police, non-governmental organizations are banned, gatherings are broken up and human rights activists are arrested. The prosecution of the anti-government journalist Mohamed Zine al-Abidine is a current example. But I also expect that in a resolution like this we will self-critically question the EU's policy in Sudan. That is why we have tabled green amendments. We problematize EU cooperation with Sudan on migration issues. We also call for the EU and the Member States to restrict their diplomatic relations without substantial improvements in the human rights situation. In spring I spoke to human rights activists myself in Khartoum, all of whom fear that the EU's strong focus on border protection and security will lead to restraint on human rights issues. I share this concern. It would be fatal for Sudan if the EU were to even partially turn away from the catastrophic humanitarian and human rights situation in favor of short-term interests. Sudan is currently the only country whose incumbent head of state is wanted by the International Criminal Court for war crimes and genocide by arrest warrant. This week the Sudanese President Al-Bashir was in Uganda. Unfortunately, Uganda did nothing to refer him to the International Criminal Court. The High Representative has publicly criticized this. I expressly support this. The EU must continue to consistently demand cooperation with the International Criminal Court.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: author. - Mr. President, the GUE / NGL group did not associate itself with this resolution, not that the case of Mr. Zine al-Abidine is not symbolic of violations of press freedom in Sudan, a press which endlessly undergoes direct or indirect censorship, notably through the regular confiscation of newspapers, but because it falls short of the human rights violations perpetrated in this country. NGOs continue to tell us that the situation remains unchanged there, especially in Darfur. The bombing continues and there are even reports of the use of chemical weapons. In addition, there is no security for the population outside the camps. However, President Al-Bashir, still under an arrest warrant from the International Criminal Court, wants to dismantle these camps at the same time when the UN is drastically decreasing, namely by 44%, the presence of UNAMID. I fear that the human rights situation in Sudan may be sacrificed on the altar of European migration policies and Saudi friends, given the weight of Sudanese troops in Yemen. It may even make our “rights” mission even more difficult in December. I sincerely regret it.

name: Soraya Post
text: Author. - Mr President! In 2016, the world's eyes were on Donald Trump's heated campaign speech on fake news. In the same year, nine journalists were arrested in more authoritarian countries on charges of fake news. In 2015, there were two reported cases. We do not have figures for 2017 yet, but the trend is very clear. How we as democracies act can mean differences between a life in freedom and a life in prison for journalists. Sudan is a good example of this. This year, the EU is investing € 1.7 million to fund projects that promote democratic principles in Sudan, with a special focus on, among other things, the media. With the rising star of the United States, the EU must take the fight for human rights seriously. In agreements and partnerships with third countries, we must focus on human rights clauses, and when they are not met, they must be accompanied by tangible consequences. I would also like to take the opportunity to recommend Forbidden Stories, a project that Reporters Without Borders and the Freedom Voices Network is launching this November to secure material from threatened journalists and make it possible to continue their work if they are arrested or killed.

name: Javier Nart
text: Author. - Mr President, the definition of Sudan is a regime presided over by a criminal, by a fugitive from justice and by a regime and a president who have been responsible for the genocides in Yebel Marra, Yebel Nuba and the Darfur area, and the repression of his own people for many years. The situation in Sudan simply means that we are dealing with a regime where the Janjauids in the Darfur area and the National Security Agency are in command, they are the all-powerful and, consequently, the pillars of the regime. Freedoms do not exist and freedom of the press is a myth, even if they have signed all or some of the international declarations. In any case, the case of Mohamed Zin al-Abidín is only one example of a general situation, of a country subjected to barbaric repression, to barbaric exploitation. This is the situation in Sudan. Mohamed Zin al-Abidin is simply an anecdote in a ghastly category.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, the situation of human, civil and political rights in Sudan continues to be worrying. Especially alarming is the state of freedom of expression. There are numerous reports about security services intervening in the activities of journalists, intimidating and censoring them. Mohamed Zine al-Abidine is just one of them. He has been taken to court for criticising the alleged corruption of President al-Bashir’s family. The editor of the newspaper al-Tayar was fined for publishing his article. Last year there were at least 44 cases of confiscated publications and the publication of three newspapers was suspended.  We urge the Sudanese authorities to end all forms of harassment and intimidation of journalists, and immediately review charges against Mohamed Zine al-Abidine. More importantly, the Sudanese Government is called upon to implement in a good spirit fundamental human rights, including freedom of expression. I thank Commissioner Stylianides for raising the issue of fundamental rights in Sudan during his recent visit to this country, but more needs to be done. The European Union should be mainstreaming human rights in our relations with third countries at all times.

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, again we observe the heinous measures which dictatorships are willing to use in order to silence even the slightest criticism – legitimate criticism. Yet we act surprised. By this time we ought to know to what lengths authoritarian regimes are ready to go in order to silence any perceived threats. As a former journalist I realise the indispensable role of a free press in any state grounded in the rule of law. External scrutiny is a fundamental aspect of holding political representatives accountable to the people.  The European Union must condemn the unjust sentencing of Mohamed Zine al-Abidine and Osman Mirgani, and increase the pressure on the Sudanese regime. The President and his companions must cease their actions. The people of Sudan too deserve to live in freedom, in security and democracy.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, dictatorships do not like critical journalists. That is why we must continue to denounce the human rights violations they commit. This is our duty even in the face of the oppressed Sudanese people. With this resolution we denounce the repeated violation of freedom of expression and of the press and the mistreatment of journalist Mohamed Zine al-Abidine and his editor Osman Mirghani. These cases are an indication of the backwardness of human rights in Sudan. The autocratic regime of Omar al-Bashir proves to be liberticide and employs the police in punitive expeditions against those who denounce corruption. Sudan needs to feel close to us in supporting the denouncing initiatives that come from the Sudanese people themselves. The Sudanese authorities are committed to respecting human rights and fundamental freedoms enshrined in international law, including freedom of expression.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mohamed Zine al-Abidine wrote an article about alleged corruption by the President of Sudan, Mr al-Bashir, who of course is accused of many worse crimes including the gravest ones – crimes against humanity, genocide and war crimes – but he is avoiding facing trial. Al-Abidine did what a journalist is supposed to do – shed light on those in power – but is now being sentenced to five years as one of many critics that are silenced.  We call on the Sudanese authorities to review these outrageous charges and to respect all people’s rights. The government should at least adhere to its own commitments under the Cotonou Agreement, but also to the Declaration on Media Freedom in the Arab World. We in the EU should step up our efforts to make sure that people’s rights are respected in Sudan, including the freedom of expression online and offline.  I would suggest that by only focusing on managing migration we are not doing that, we are not prioritising respect for human rights. In fact we may well give people a good excuse to repress and to keep people down. I think that is the wrong development also from our side.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, according to the Reporters Without Borders World Press Freedom Index, Sudan ranks 174th out of 180 countries evaluated. Government authorities in Sudan routinely detain and accuse journalists and confiscate the publication of various periodicals. In 2016, there were a total of 44 such cases involving twelve different newspapers. Muhammad Zayn al-Abidin criticized the alleged corruption in the family of Sudanese President al-Bashir, as has been stated several times. He was sentenced to 5 years on probation and appealed against the verdict. His case is just one of many violations of fundamental rights and freedoms in Sudan. We know that freedom of the press and freedom of expression is a basic precondition for the establishment and development of a free society. As a European Union, we should therefore strongly condemn the persecution of journalists and severely sanction its initiators. On the contrary, we must provide all possible support to all those who are fighting for the survival of the independent press in Sudan. In the case of Muhammad Zain al-Abidin, we must demand a fair trial.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in a country where widespread violations of human rights have been extensively reported by international organisations such as Waging Peace, the case of Mohamed Zine al-Abidine is extremely worrying. His arrest and imprisonment follows repeated acts of intimidation and harassment, conducted by the authorities against journalists. It is clear that the Sudanese Government seeks to silence critical voices by means of judicial harassment, censorship and confiscation of newspapers. These unacceptable actions have been taking place in the context of total disregard by Mr Omar al—Bashir, a total disregard for human rights and international law. He still has not been brought to justice regarding the grave accusations of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity that were filed against him several years ago. The EU must use all diplomatic channels at its disposal to urge the Sudanese authorities to release Mohamed Zine al—Abidine and all the human rights defenders, journalists and political opponents behind bars in Sudan. High Representative Federica Mogherini must also put all her efforts into presenting Mr al—Bashir to the International Criminal Court.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Sudan ranks 174th out of 180 in terms of press freedom. This gives you a clear idea of the context in which journalist Mohamed Zine al-Abidine and his editor-in-chief are facing charges for criticising alleged corruption in the family of the Sudanese President al-Bashir, a president who has escaped justice for organising war crimes and crimes against humanity. These journalists are not alone in facing repression. The Sudanese intelligence agency has been waging an actual war on freedom of information and expression for years. There is no hope for democracy if these basic values continue to be threatened.  My main concern is that the EU gives EUR 100 million in aid to Sudan on migration. We need to ensure that not a euro is diverted to fund surveillance and IT systems that could assist in repression of journalists and media. I think that the High Representative, the Commission and Member States need to step up support to civil society that can help and reform press and printing legislation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we must first note that Sudan has not ratified the revised version of the Cotonou Agreement in 2005. Its president, al-Bashir, is accused of genocide and is currently evading referral to the International Criminal Court. It is clear that the problem of freedom of the press is one of the problems of circumvention of fundamental rights and freedoms in Sudan. Censorship prevails and any newspaper that dares to criticize the regime is shut down. We have repeatedly seized newspapers that have been highly critical of the regime and, of course, the latest case of journalists, most notably al-Abidine, who criticized the regime for corruption in the newspaper. The European Union must take concrete action against the Sudanese regime and ensure, of course, that any European aid given goes directly to the people and not to the regime.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament has a duty to stand up for the unjustly prosecuted, we have a duty to promote media freedom.We don't even have to go that far.Governments that have a problem and are afraid of freedom of speech are the first to intervene against freedom of the press and journalists.Let's look at Malta, Turkey, Russia.And Sudan has economic as well as political problems, and so the government is persecuting opponents and people who are fighting for a free Sudan.Recently, Parliament supported Petr Jašek and his colleagues who, as humanitarian workers, supported the unjustly prosecuted.So let us also now support Muhammad Zain al-Abidin and other journalists who are helping to find the truth in Sudan.At least their bravery deserves our great support.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I want to support this Resolution in favor of the release of Mohamed Zin al-Abidín.Sudan is one of the countries where there is a lack of freedom and an obvious lack of human rights.The Sudanese regime has subdued and intimidated its people, and the case of Mohamed Zin al-Abidín is an example of how the Sudanese authoritarian dictatorship is repressing the freedom of the press for reporting on the corruption of the President of Sudan and hisfamily.From the European Union, ladies and gentlemen, we must condemn what is happening in Sudan.Not only in the case that concerns us today, but in all the violations of freedom of expression and rights that occur in that African country.As you know, Sudan receives financial aid from the European institutions.And such aid must also be limited to Sudan meeting the democratic requirements of respect for freedom of expression and respect for human rights.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as you know, I am taking this item on behalf of Commission Vice-President Mogherini. The European Union continues to express serious concerns about the human rights situation in Sudan, which is marked by human rights violations and abuses, including restrictions on peaceful protests, media censorship, harassment and arbitrary detention of human rights defenders, the crackdown on civil society organisations and restrictions on freedom of religion. In particular, freedom of expression and press and media freedoms are also under serious threat. The security authorities continue to seize print runs, to suspend independent newspapers indefinitely, and arbitrarily to arrest and detain journalists for the critical content of their writing. Such concerns were highlighted in a statement issued by the European Union, with like-minded partners, in December 2016. Despite some progress that Sudan has recently shown on humanitarian access and establishing a cessation of hostilities in conflict areas, changes in the domestic setting remain limited. Civil society organisations are largely inhibited from operating at full capacity, with crackdowns on protesters, human rights defenders, journalists, members of the opposition and religious minorities. The case of Mohamed Zine al-Abidine is emblematic of the problems that affect the whole country. In 2012, this journalist was detained for two weeks because of an opinion article denouncing the abuse of power by the highest circles of Sudanese leadership, which was published by the newspaper al-Tayar. As a consequence, the newspaper was immediately suspended for two years. On 23 October the Sudanese court sentenced Zine al-Abidine to a three-year suspended sentence and the editor-in-chief, Osman Mirgani, to six months in jail for criminal conspiracy and disruption of the public order. Mirgani was released the following day after a fine for his release was paid. The European Union has closely monitored the aforementioned prosecution and other similar cases through which the Sudanese Government tries to maintain control over the information landscape in the country. The Union will continue to call on the Government to respect freedom of expression and enable space for civil society. The Union also remains committed to supporting human rights defenders and civil society at large through various means at our disposal. The Union is, for example, supporting several projects on press freedom, as well as civic and human-rights education in Sudan through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.  The European Union strongly encourages the Government of Sudan to show full commitment to peace and reconciliation in Sudan. This includes the strengthening of the democratisation process, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, as well as the adoption of genuine political and economic reforms addressing the root causes of conflict. The EU is ready to engage with the Government of Sudan on these issues.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place today from 12 noon.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for a debate on five motions for resolutions concerning the terrorist attacks in Somalia (2017/2962 (RSP)).

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, a lorry in Mogadishu, loaded with explosives, tragically resulted in the deaths of 385 people, with many others injured and more than 100 buried without identification, due to the severity of their injuries. Their loved ones will never know who they are. Somalia is a land plagued with intractable problems: terrorism, drought, famine, refugee camps, crippling debt, child soldiers and the worst corruption in the world for the tenth year running. Add to this the allegations of sexual violence by troops from the UN-backed African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM), the force mobilised to protect the Somalian people from extremist groups, and it is clear that this is still a very fragile nation, teetering on the edge. The election of President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed was a milestone in this country’s recent history and there are some positive signs that President Mohamed is committed now to continuing the fight against al-Shabaab. By appointing representatives from different clans to ministerial office, he is also building unity across a very fractured society. The EU, too, must now do what it can by encouraging dialogue between the social sectors and ensuring that allegations against AMISOM troops are thoroughly investigated and that those responsible are rapidly brought to justice.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: author. - Madam President, today I would like to speak about an uncomfortable truth. We cannot talk about terrorism in Somalia without first pointing out the elephant sitting in the room: a state, Saudi Arabia; One figure, 25% of its trade is with the European Union. We are your first business partner. The uncomfortable truth: Saudi Arabia is the founding state and the biggest promoter of Wahhabism, and is a preferred partner of the European Union. Yes, of this European Union of political coherence. Terrorism is fought with sustainable development, with integration and social cohesion, with redistribution of wealth, not with militarization. Stabilizing Somalia requires that we end the hypocrisy of our foreign action. Development aid should not be conditioned on cooperation in migration policy, but should focus on achieving the SDGs. But sadly, the biggest expense by far from the international community in Somalia is military. We would not object if drones distributed social inclusion and human rights, but we know that - a product of our political coherence - this is far from being the case.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Madam President, in October this year hundreds of people senselessly lost their lives in Somalia. Some are still missing. This is the latest in a long line of acts of violence, extremism and terror – attacks for the most part attributed to al-Shabaab.  These terrible acts have occurred in the wider context of internal conflict and instability including acute food insecurity and the fact that more than two million people have been forced to leave their homes, as internally displaced persons or refugees, in the region. We must take a strong stand in condemning these acts of violence as well as addressing the situation that Somalia is facing when it comes to nationwide security, stability and justice – a situation which will continue to worsen without strong action in defence of civil society, human rights, democracy and rule of law.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: Author. - Last month, Somalia was hit by two horrific bomb attacks, which left 400 dead, hundreds injured and dozens missing. I am therefore glad that we pay attention to this this morning. After all, terrorist attacks in Africa all too often remain a minor footnote. So today let us express our condolences to the victims and their families. Somalia is a country that is in any case very difficult. It suffers from drought, malnutrition and conflict. More than a million people have been displaced. What worries me most is the increasing violence and extremism, including among children. We urgently need to do something about that. We must take steps in the fight against impunity so that perpetrators are punished. We must also focus on the rehabilitation of child soldiers. Children should play, not fight. We must prevent child soldiers from being recruited by criminals. We need to see if the displaced people can return, because more than a million people in Somalia are displaced. Let's bet on that. Finally, as Europe, we must keep our humanitarian commitments. Let's work together to make Somalia once again a country where children can play, grow up healthy and have food. Thank you.

name: Joachim Zeller
text: Author. - Madam President! After Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed was elected President of Somalia in February of this year, there was faint hope that the situation in Somalia could stabilize and that terrorism in the country could also be combated more vigorously.
