After the cowardly bombings in the center of the Somali capital, in Mogadishu, in February of this year, this hope seems to be dashed. Hundreds of dead, wounded and missing people are to be mourned. We must not be indifferent to their fate, our sympathy belongs to their families. This raises the question of how capable the government and the security authorities of Somalia are to protect their citizens. And the African Union's Somalia mission, Amison, does not seem to be able to effectively suppress the actions of terrorist organizations such as Al-Shabaab - on the contrary: It is reported that, for example, 5,000 Burundian soldiers have given up their positions without a fight and have extradited the civilian population ordered to protect them from the Al-Shabaab militia. Amison was and is largely funded by the EU through the African Peace Facility. We should urgently review the effectiveness of this aid, now that a Court of Auditors report casts serious doubts on the effectiveness and efficiency of this facility. The international community is called upon to ensure that Somalia does not continue to be destabilized and that terrorist organizations such as Al-Shabaab do not pose a threat to the entire region, for example, if we think of the politically unclear situation in Kenya, where there are hundreds of thousands of refugees from Somalia. The colleagues mentioned that the geopolitical situation naturally also plays a role. North of the Gulf of Aden we have the civil war in Yemen, now another destabilization of the situation in Somalia. This can become a wildfire that we are not indifferent to can.Before further human lives can be deplored, action is required, also from the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, now we are speaking about Somalia which is a very tragic situation because in Somalia, first of all, they have a famine as a result of four rainy seasons having failed, leading to 800 000 refugees and between one and a half to two million displaced persons. On top of that, it is unfortunately a very corrupt country, with Transparency International rating it for the tenth year running as the most corrupt in the world, and of course the worst of all is al-Shabaab, the terrorist organisation which caused major devastation in October.  But there is great hope for Somalia. Number one, they have a newly elected President who seems to be a good man and, as pointed out by Charles Tannock, is trying to incorporate as many groups as possible in government. Secondly, many females and young people have been elected to government. Thirdly, the people had the courage to protest publicly against al-Shabaab.  The European Union has done a lot of work here, giving EUR 3.4 billion in aid between 2015 and 2020, 60% of what Somalia has got from the world community. I think we need to work with the President and others: firstly, to establish their own security forces – as Mr Zeller said, the African Union Mission in Somali (AMISOM) is not working – and secondly, to try and fight that terrible terrorist group al-Shabaab and keep young people away from them and then we can make progress.  There is a great opportunity here. Let’s grasp it.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after years of conflict which has caused immense damage to Somalia's population and economy, the country was beginning to see glimpses of peace, a return to life and hope.Then, Islamist terrorism with al-Shabab struck with extreme ferocity, with cowardly attacks that caused thousands of victims, which this resolution intends strongly to condemn, reaffirming Europe's closeness to this peace process.Instead of giving in to fear, the Somali people reacted, showing their strength and ability to remain united.It is now up to us to remain by their side, to support this population exhausted by decades of conflict in an autonomous path of peace, involving international and regional actors.Because peace in Somalia, Madam President, Commissioner, means peace and well-being for all the countries of the Horn of Africa as well.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I convey deepest sympathy to the families of all the casualties and the Somalian people condemning this appalling terrorist act. Taking into account all the difficulties mentioned by the author Mr Charles Tannock, the decade-long combating of al-Shabaab’s terrorist activity is a very difficult task. There is some hope after the inauguration of President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed and his pledge to get rid of this terrorist organisation’s acts in Somalia. The truck bomb attack was first of all probably a reaction to this. We have to build the resilience of Somalian society and assist the government which is willing to combat it.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the attacks in Mogadishu on 14 and 28 October resulted in unprecedented numbers of innocent people killed. I wish to convey my condolences to the victims’ families and loved ones, and actually, to all Somalis. I am glad the EU offered emergency response quickly and hope that there will be more efforts by the international community to continue to build resilience and address structural problems. This should include meeting the needs of the 400 000 children who are suffering from malnutrition. Access to aid organisations should be granted. It is important to see the connection between the different elements that can lead to the recruitment of people to terrorist organisations. We must also acknowledge that terrorism is a global problem and needs to be addressed in unity. I think it is a shared responsibility of the international community and I hope it will be met by all.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, our most absolute condemnation of the terrorism that plagues Somalia and the attack that killed more than three hundred and fifty people. But we are losing the battle by losing values. Not only does military optics work. And even more so when it is a carbon copy of that war on terror that the Bush Administration promoted, that Obama followed, and that President Trump has followed. We see them, their results, not just in Somalia but in Afghanistan and elsewhere. The extrajudicial and extraterritorial assassination by drones is not only an affront to the law, but it causes unacceptable innocent victims who, in addition, are a breeding ground for terrorism. Nor are initiatives like the Khartoum process to outsource border control the solution. Nobody emigrates for pleasure and the militarization of that border control is not the solution, but investing all means in sustainable development as equals, attacking the financing of terrorism, clearly pointing out the culprits, such as the Saudis and Wahhabism, acting with regional actors to stabilize and combat terrorism.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Somalia is one of Africa's greatest tragedies. Torn apart since the end of the Cold War, the country is faced with all the plagues of the African continent: Islamism, ethnic divisions, looting of resources and Western and African interference. We often fail in development in Africa because we lack a comprehensive and conscious approach to the ground. We too often forget that development and security must go hand in hand. All the same, I would like to underline the courage of the external services, of our external services, in particular the Commission, which wanted to set up there, on the spot. This goes in the good direction of a ground approach. We must, however, avoid an approach that is too often liberal, because we believe that development can be done without a state and without protectionism. In this, the Lomé agreements are much more advanced than the current Cotonou ones. I am sure that joint parliamentary work will lead positively to this approach to co-development.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Madam President, first of all, I do not think there is a sane person who does not unequivocally condemn the terrorist attacks of fanatical Islamists. There are 300 dead and 300 wounded in the recent bombing in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, and authorities believe al-Shabaab is acting. Somalia is a country that for decades has been plagued by instability, armed conflict, civil war, malnutrition, epidemics - such as cholera - and, of course, has a huge problem of corruption. Western interventions, at times, failed to solve the problems and simply replaced one corrupt oligarchy with another. Even the military, backed by Western governments, continues to recruit minors to this day. We are strongly opposed to interfering in the internal affairs of third countries, but we must identify the sources of funding for all of them in Somalia and strictly forbid any company operating in the Union to have any financial transaction which, as it turns out, is the main motivation. of all these conflicts. I would like to mention to the House that these days in Greece there is a deadly flood in which 16 people have lost their lives, 26 have been injured and 6 are missing. I hope the European Union will help the situation.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the best way to honor the 358 victims of the horrific terrorist attack in Mogadishu on 14 October this year is to continue our efforts to rebuild a functioning Somali state. The Commission deserves thanks for the swift response and assistance in providing medical care to the victims of this assassination. According to Transparency International, Somalia is the most corrupt country in the world. The consequences of this corruption are clear. In Somalia, 400,000 children are malnourished. Three million Somalis live on the brink of famine. We cannot yet rule out the threat of a nationwide famine. Of course, terrorists benefit from such a broken society. The fight against terrorism in Somalia begins with the provision of basic necessities for the people of Somalia. The European Union must continue this humanitarian aid. At the same time, it should mobilize the entire international community, especially neighboring and other states in the region, so that each can contribute to the end of Somalia in territories controlled by more terrorists than the Somali government.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President!The horrific attack on October 21st in Mogadishu once again put long-suffering Somalia into the focus of world interest for a short time.There has been no law here for a quarter of a century because statehood only exists in rudiments.This is also one of the reasons for the increasing destabilization of the entire region.The Horn of Africa is one of the most unstable areas in the world.The tragic events should draw our attention to the region and give rise to new political efforts.In addition to diplomatic efforts, Europe should above all support the Somali diaspora.This is the only hope for a new Somalia.Most importantly, we need to increase humanitarian aid and keep our promises.We should also urge Saudi Arabia to end its support for the Wahhabi extremists.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, the growing presence of the Islamic State group in Somalia could become a significant threat if it manages to attract jihadist fighters who will flee the collapsing bastions in Syria and Iraq. . According to a UN report, Islamic State militants in Somalia have multiplied. As we all know, the Islamist and very dangerous group al-Shabab, a terrorist organization that has sought to establish full control over Muslims in the country's three torn regions and enforce sharia law, has existed in Somalia for more than a decade. Recently, President Mohammed Abdullah Mohammed expressed the position that he had declared a state of war against the al-Shabab group. We believe that, as a community, we must support Somalia on the path to stabilization, because we saw what happened in North Africa when the countries there disintegrated and the Pandora's box opened, flooding Europe with a wave of migrants and violence. We need to help stop terrorism in its infancy so that we do not fall back into the situation of Europe being a lifeline and putting our countries and citizens at risk.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, in recent years, the EU has shown its strong and longstanding commitment to supporting Somalia and its people. The EU’s engagement in the country has intensified over the years, with the Union remaining the largest donor in terms of both political engagement and financial and technical support and expertise. Unfortunately, the ongoing conflicts and power struggles within Somalia have destabilised the country’s political and security environment, leading to the rise of terrorism and large refugee movements both within the country and beyond its borders. In less than a year the terrorist group al-Shabaab, the local branch of al-Qa’ida, has conducted more than 20 attacks in Mogadishu, leaving hundreds of people dead and more than a thousand injured. Terrorist attacks weaken and reverse the gains made today. Therefore, I call on the EU to use active diplomacy to encourage the international community to remain strongly engaged, through a process of state-building and security in Somalia. The EU and the international community should improve political and security stability in the country, because terrorism is a common threat that must be tackled on the basis of full cooperation.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the situation in Somalia has been difficult and bleak for a long time.An internally divided country has fallen victim to the rise of religious extremism and related violence.Unfortunately, terrorist attacks in the area are very common and are also linked to an act of revenge.The same was the case last month, when a Somali soldier detonated a truck in the capital filled with several hundred kilograms of explosives and killed over 350 people.This cowardly act was a reaction to another, equally cowardly act that took place in August.7 adult unarmed farmers and three children were killed by government and US troops in the south of the country.I therefore want to appeal that our condemnation of shameful acts should not be governed by the flag under which they were committed.When it comes to defending the innocent, we must not look at who we consider allies, but measure everyone with the same meter.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a thought goes to the families and victims of the cowardly and vile terrorist attacks of an Islamist origin, of course. But now Europe must act, Europe must react. How can Europe react? Stopping the financing channels of Islamist terrorism, primarily the trafficking of illegal immigrants. In order to defeat terrorism, Europe must defend its borders and cannot continue to pay what is a crazy and criminal welcome. If we were to reflect for a few seconds together on the motives of the recent Islamist attack in Somalia, which involved 358 deaths, we will identify at least two motives. The first motive is the goal of establishing Sharia law in Somalia, but the second goal, more profound and one of business and profit, is to create fear, create destabilization of the Somali people to push them on the criminal path of clandestine departures to Europe. As many as 200,000 Somalis have reached Italy in the last five years. So, a Europe that defends borders is a Europe that wants to permanently shut off the taps to terrorist financing, a Europe that defends borders is a Europe that wants to say enough and defeat terrorism, a Europe that defends borders is a Europe that really wants to eradicate the problem of terrorism in our country.

name: Wajid Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the bombing in central Mogadishu on 14 October was one of the most lethal terrorist attacks in recent years. It killed over 350 people, left more than 200 injured, and many are still missing. Al-Shabaab, the organisation responsible for such barbarity, had not itself foreseen the scale of its own operation. They did not even claim public responsibility for the loss of so many lives, for fear of angering the citizens and losing support for their insurgency. The population did not even have time to mourn for these victims before yet another brutal attack took place on 28 October. Somalia is under attack, and it needs our support to continue. I therefore appeal to the African Union and the United Nations: this is not the time to withdraw troops from the country. We cannot abandon Somalia in their time of need. Only with a joint effort can we hope to defeat the terrorists and soon restore peace in Somalia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we unequivocally condemn the terrorist attack that took place on 14 October in Mogadishu and which had many casualties; 358 dead and 228 wounded. A terrorist act by al-Shabaab, the well-known Islamist terrorist organization, which of course constantly recruits children and other citizens in Somalia, precisely because there is poverty. 75% of the population lives below the poverty line, malnutrition has affected 400,000 children and there are too many refugees. The poor economic situation in Somalia is therefore a fertilizer for terrorism; 420,000 refugees are in Kenya alone. Do you understand, then, that drastic intervention is needed in order to stabilize the situation and, above all, to have economic development in Somalia, so that we do not even have illegal immigrants in Europe and, above all, so that these people can support their homeland.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Madam President!Somalia has been a regular victim of horrific and cowardly terror attacks for a long time, including the Mogadishu bombing in October, one of the bloodiest attacks in the world.Almost all of these attacks have one common denominator: Ash-Shabab.Therefore, there is no doubt that comprehensive measures are necessary to liquidate this terrorist organization.I believe that the result of the February presidential election and the coming to power of President Abdullahi Mohamed offer a chance for positive changes in this direction.However, it should be remembered that apart from strengthening the security forces, additional measures are equally important, such as limiting the sources of funding for Ash-Shabab by controlling the origin of natural resources or reducing the risk of recruiting young people by Ash-Shabab, for example by increasing the number of jobs.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, on behalf of Vice-President Mogherini I want to indicate to the House the view of the Commission in relation to the matter that has been raised arising from the terrorist attacks in Somalia. On 14 October, Somalia suffered one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in recent history, when a truck filled with explosives detonated in a busy area of Mogadishu. Some 350 civilians died and many more were injured. Only two weeks later, on 28 October, another deadly terror attack hit Mogadishu.  The High Representative and Vice-President Federica Mogherini spoke to President Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed (Farmajo) to express condolences at both occasions and reaffirm the European Union’s long-term commitment to Somalia and its people. I am sure everybody in this House will join with me in expressing our sincerest condolences to the victims and their families.  Terrorist attacks are not uncommon in Somalia and the terrorist organisation al-Shabaab unfortunately remains a continuous threat to the building of a peaceful and democratic society benefiting the Somali people. In the last few years, thanks to the collective work of the Somalis themselves, coupled with the support of the international community, Somalia – following decades of civil war, clan feuds and disarray – has seen positive political developments. Slowly a federal state with institutions is being established.  AMISOM, the African Union’s peace-keeping operation, has been essential in providing a security space for political progress to happen. The European Union, including its Member States, is by far the largest supporter of Somalia, with a collective contribution of EUR 3.5 billion in 2015 to 2020. The important and positive progress cannot be reversed. It is essential for Somalia’s advancement and security, and it is important for stability in the region and beyond. The Federal Government of Somalia now has to show leadership and determination. Only political inclusivity, joint commitment and unity between the federal and regional levels will move Somalia out of this constant crisis mode. We therefore welcome the recent meetings convened by President Farmajo and by Prime Minister Hassan Ali Khayre between the federal government and the federal member states. The security situation has to be tackled up-front, and the concrete building of a Somali-owned security architecture in line with the agreed stability pact has to move forward. Equally, the federal project must move forward, fundamentally in finalising the constitutional review to resolve the outstanding issues of power and resource sharing between the federal government and the federal member states. All of these reforms should allow Somalia to take ownership of its own security and its own economic potential. In turn, it will create the conditions for AMISOM’s gradual draw-down.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place today at 12 noon.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: written.- Our delegation regrets the heavy toll taken by the attack on 14 October in Mogadishu.Somalia has been strangled by extremist violence for years.Attacks, executions and kidnappings dominate daily life.With this latest attack, however, the brutality reached an all-time low: 358 innocent civilians lost their lives and many hundreds were injured.We should never get used to terror.Not even in Somalia.That is why we call on the international community to assist the country in its fight against terror and thus pave the way to peace and stability.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – We are all too familiar with the horrific effects of terror in Europe in these recent years, yet we must also focus on Africa, where terrorism is devastating Somalia. The country has suffered another terrorist attack in the form of a truck bomb, which struck Mogadishu. In this particular strike, more than 300 people were killed and 500 were injured. This attack is unfortunately another chapter in the story of terrorism in Somalia. Mogadishu has seen four separate bombings in the year 2017 alone. Hundreds have been killed as a result. This issue is a crisis for both Somalia and Africa. The EU and Africa have had a prosperous and beneficial relationship for many years, however that relationship is being jeopardised as a result of these repeated terrorist attacks. In order to ensure a better future for both Africa and the EU, we must deliver technical and financial support to the Somali Government to help them fight terrorism.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: - I strongly condemn the bloody terrorist attack carried out on October 14 this year in Mogadishu, which resulted in the death of at least 358 people and the remaining 228 injured. Terrorist attacks, shootings in public places, executions and kidnappings in Mogadishu have intensified especially in recent months. Given Somalia's limited ability to protect its citizens from violence and the risk of the country returning to an anarchy, the African Union should seriously consider extending the African Union Mission in Somalia (AMISOM) beyond 2018. In addition, I urge the European Commission to allocate more resources to under the African Peace Facility to counter terrorism and radicalization. I also ask the Council of the European Union to consider the possibility of extending the mandate of the Military Training Mission in Somalia (EUTM Somalia) to include anti-terrorist activities, while increasing the personnel of the mission. The chronic destabilization of this country is contributing to the massive flight of Somalis from their country and the search for better living conditions in Europe. The migration crisis of recent years has shown that our possibilities of helping in this matter are limited, therefore I am asking for the support of the European Union for actions aimed at solving the problem of migration at its source.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on six motions for resolutions concerning Madagascar (2017/2963 (RSP)).

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: Author. Madam President, Madagascar is the fourth largest island in the world. It is an area rich in wealth, but its people are very poor, as 92% of the population lives on less than two US dollars a day. In 1980, Madagascar fell into the clutches of the International Monetary Fund, which implemented its well-known programs, resulting in poverty, unemployment and the seizure of public wealth. It is now under the influence of China, which has put it on the Silk Road, with infrastructure projects and with Chineseization of the economy, which has been filled with cheap Chinese products and has disintegrated, resulting in strikes and resistance. This is the situation in the country, with a political crisis and a conflict between the government and the judiciary, due to the Claudine case, which is related to bribery. It is obvious that the intervention of the European Union is needed to restore normalcy and to facilitate this people, in order for it to be able to exploit its wealth-producing resources and economy and find itself in political normalcy, especially as it walks towards the elections.

name: Jordi Solé
text: author. - Madam President, Madagascar is facing a highly problematic exploitation of its natural resources. 36,000 hectares of its rainforest are lost every year, often to the benefit of businesses owned by local oligarchs. Many mining permits have been granted by the former transitional government in non-transparent procedures, without consulting the local population and without taking into account environmental impacts. Few environmental crimes are prosecuted. It is quite a different story for environmental activists who oppose the looting of their country and who regularly find themselves in prison or before judges, such as Clovis Razafimalala. This activist denounced the trafficking and illegal logging of rosewood. He was therefore detained for over nine months, on trumped-up charges of rebellion, destruction of public documents and goods, and arson. He was eventually given a five-year suspended prison sentence. The UN special rapporteur on human rights and the environment, John Knox, cites a problem of corruption in the judiciary to explain such facts. Madagascar is also reviewing its mining code. It is very important that this revision results in a text guaranteeing elementary principles, such as the compulsory use of impact studies, the prior consultation of the inhabitants affected by the mining activities, the possibilities of appeal and the granting of permits conditional on the strict limitation of the transformation of the site during the extraction activities, the reconstitution of the site at the end of these activities and the compensation of the environmental impacts. The government should also take this opportunity to review the highly questionable operating permits granted by the former government. I'm glad that the joint resolution addresses, among other things, all of these burning issues.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. - Madam President, since 2009 in Madagascar we have seen an increase in the extractivist economy of mining, forestry and agri-food resources by multinationals that has been directly coupled with an alarming persecution of journalists, environmentalists and human rights defenders, who denounce Government corruption and this predatory economic model of environmental rights and resources. It is essential to point out the relationship of the increase in sexual violence against women with mining exploitation areas, in a country - Madagascar - where women still do not have the right to legal abortion. We must demand from the Government of Madagascar scrupulous compliance with human rights, as well as the fulfillment of the sexual and reproductive rights of women. But our demand is also for multinationals that are predators of resources and, many times, that violate rights. For all this, we also demand that the European Union support the binding treaty that is being debated at the United Nations, respecting human rights by multinationals. It is up to us too, ladies and gentlemen, to take part and put ourselves precisely on the side of the people and human rights, preventing the plundering of multinationals.

name: Soraya Post
text: author. – Madam President, the human rights situation in Madagascar right now is extremely serious. The everyday reality of human rights defenders is intimidation, threats, lack of freedom of association and expression, and judicial harassment – in clear contravention of international human rights norms. We need to send a clear message to the Malagasy authorities that the harassment of human rights defenders and journalists must stop. They must be allowed to carry out their work in safety.  The court sentences that have been handed down to human rights defenders and journalists to force them to stop their work, such as in the case of Raleva, must be quashed.  The EU and its Member States must invest in providing support and protection to human rights defenders; it is our obligation.

name: Louis Michel
text: author. - Madam President, Commissioner, one year away from the presidential and legislative elections, all the ferments of a pre- and post-electoral crisis have come together: seizure of all the levers of power, suppression of freedoms for non-governmental parties, lack of good governance with a very high level of corruption and embezzlement of public funds, arbitrary imprisonment, harassment of journalists, including investigative journalists, and of human and environmental rights defenders, non-compliance the principle of the separation of powers, state interference in judicial affairs, extrajudicial executions, popular justice in the face of the impunity of certain law enforcement officers. Colleague Jordi Solé has already mentioned the case of Clovis Razafimalala, I will not come back to it. There is another case, that of Mr. Ravela, who was given a two-year suspended prison sentence just for daring to seek proof that a Chinese mining company had been granted the necessary mining and environmental permits to sue. his activities. This resolution is truly timely. It couldn't be tough enough.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. - Madam President, many rejoiced in 2013 that Madagascar was moving in the right direction, but that there was still room for improvement. But they were not right. This improvement turned out to be only temporary. The current government should respect the foundations of the rule of law and allow the judiciary to decide freely on cases of corruption or human rights. Fundamental freedoms, including the most important freedom of expression, must be respected. I hope that next year's elections will be democratic and transparent and that the European Union will be involved in upholding all rights. But this is not just a problem in Madagascar, it is generally a problem in most African states. The situation in Madagascar is just the imaginary tip of the iceberg. Human rights violations are taking place across Africa. Research by organizations such as Human Right Watch and Amnesty International has shown that restrictions on political opposition, gender and racial discrimination, child labor, forced marriages, religious freedom, corruption and even slavery are common practices. Often the situation goes so far that people are completely illegitimate, arrested, or even killed, and often because of miserable money or natural resources, such as in Madagascar. In addition, radical Islam is spreading in Africa, which is increasingly disrupting the minds of the people there. There is huge room for improvement on the issue of human rights in Africa, but we must help, as the European Union is trying in Madagascar. The European Union is the guarantor and defender of democratic values ​​and fundamental human rights and freedoms, but it must actively participate in stabilizing the situation and, through its diplomats, contribute to the rule of law and respect for human rights. The partnership between Africa and the European Union in the field of economic cooperation is important, but it should not be forgotten that our priority is to prevent conflicts and contribute to resolving them so that the situation does not escalate further. There is a need for a human rights dialogue with African countries under a European Union mandate and to promote a strong commitment to the protection of human rights, democracy and the rule of law worldwide.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner! As many speakers have already mentioned, it seemed that the elections four years ago would lead to stabilization, improvement and the creation of the rule of law. But as we can see, today's democratic standards are not respected in this country. We have all already talked about the persecution of journalists, human rights defenders and the environment, about ineffective actions by state officials, about unjustified detentions and, at the same time, about acts of lynching. I believe that, in this case, as far as Madagascar is concerned, it is very important to stop, above all, the excessive and illegal exploitation of natural resources. These are not only Madagascar's goods, but also global ones, and their overexploitation leads to ecological degradation and, above all, takes away the opportunity for future generations of the population, citizens in this country, for socio-economic development, and at the same time, as we can see, it leads to strong corruption in all levels of current power. It is certainly important to respect human rights, and also that there will be no constitutional changes in this country. I believe that next year's presidential elections will be a chance for that, and they may allow this country to remain democratic at the level of a democratic country with full cooperation and control, and I hope that we can do all this together.

name: Boris Zala
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the priority must now be on the upcoming presidential elections, to ensure that they are free and fair and that the results are accepted by all political players as legitimate. Madagascar cannot afford another slide into chaos. This is the responsibility of the current President. That is the key message of the urgency resolution. But the signs are not encouraging. The current government violates human rights on a daily basis. Madagascar is one of the poorest and worst—governed countries in Africa. The people of Madagascar are in desperate need of governance. Neither poverty nor plague can be contained without a legitimate government in place. International donors cannot operate in a state of perpetual instability. That is why the conduct of the upcoming elections is so critical to the country’s future. The EU must put maximum pressure on the government to deliver them.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it is unfortunate that we are having to discuss Madagascar today. After the last elections we were all hopeful that the situation would improve, but this is not happening. Madagascar is truly in a dire state. While the outbreak of the plague has recently been dominating the headlines, there are many other serious issues threatening the well—being of its citizens and undermining their human rights.  The reports of the government arbitrarily detaining human rights defenders, journalists and activists, and the cases of extrajudicial killing, are alarming and disturbing. This needs to end.  As Madagascar enters a new election year, the EU should be more actively engaging in helping the country to strengthen democracy and the rule of law and should provide as much technical assistance as necessary to this end.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I am wondering about the value of the recommendations on press freedom in Madagascar, when, in Europe, whistleblowers are brought to justice. What is also the moral force of the recommendations in terms of respect for fundamental rights, when European companies violate the rights of millions of workers all over the world? What is also the value of the recommendations for reforming the mining code in the Big Island, when we fail to denounce the theft of land and the exploitation of mineral resources by European companies? Because we would have done better to address these recommendations to the German company Tantalus, which has grabbed 300 kilometers of land on the backs of Malagasy peasants. In fact, as always, under the guise of human rights, it is always through economic interference, through political interference that we are pursuing what we are obsessed with here, that is to say the interests of the European Union, European countries and European multinationals.

name: Dominique Bilde
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, listening to some people, I see that they are a little out of touch with what exactly is happening in Madagascar. Madagascar's weaknesses in terms of democracy do not justify driving its population into poverty. My colleagues have rightly pointed out the dramatic consequences of the freezing of European funding from 2009 to 2014, since this country depends 50% on international aid. Madagascar is no more spared than Europe from Islamist infiltration and the terrorist risk is now tangible. In this regard, Europeans, like the entire international community, must refrain from any interference in the issue of the Muslim minority of the Khojas. Madagascar is indeed, above all, grappling with an inextricable economic situation, since the worsening of inequalities since 2005 and the failing infrastructures jeopardize any hope of recovery. Considerable effort will be needed to improve the living conditions of the 92% of Malagasy who survive on less than two euros a day. A development, for example, of farming local shrimp - the best in the world - would be a step forward. The devastation of the plague, which killed 127 people during the months of August and October, is the latest tragic symptom of this extreme destitution. The European intervention is crucial as the Malagasy authorities are struggling to cope with this health crisis which, according to the World Health Organization, should continue until April of next year. Our mobilization is therefore urgent to get Madagascar out of the rut of chronic instability of famine and disease.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the European Parliament has been one of Madagascar’s steadfast supporters on the path to consolidation of democracy and stabilization. In December 2013, we sent an election observation mission to Madagascar, in order to accompany the process of emerging from a political crisis that had lasted five years and thus to support the Malagasy people. I myself participated in this mission and I remember very well how important our presence was during this delicate phase of exiting the crisis. For me, it is essential that the country continues to move on the right track and that the next electoral process, which should take place at the end of 2018, takes place under good conditions. For this, political stability must be preserved and dialogue and the search for consensus must be privileged by political actors. This is the only possible recipe for the organization of credible elections on time. I remember, moreover, that we had received the Madagascan President in Brussels and conducted this extremely useful dialogue in this regard. If the next elections go well, I am convinced that the European Union will continue to support the country. In the immediate future, it is up to the Union - it is up to us - to use all the instruments at our disposal to support an inclusive political dialogue and to insist on respect for human rights in the perspective of the next process. electoral.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, we are talking about Madagascar and, suddenly, we see on the horizon the worst flaws of rough democracy. The scheme is now classic. The Madagascan socio-political climate borders on catastrophe. Reduced to misery, the people helplessly witness the generalization of corruption. Amnesty International echoed this last July, pointing out the wrongdoing that plagues the big island from the lowest to the highest level. The presidential election was scheduled for 2018, but now a constitutional review is popping up out of nowhere. This is the key to dilating time and postponing elections. Those who say so are not wrong. The political agenda shows a grim picture: silencing the opposition, government interference in legal proceedings, conditioning of the work of the CENI, excessive repression of activists, intimidation of journalists and punitive dispatch by law enforcement. Our resolution expresses our aversion to these violations and, at the same time, our firm support for the Malagasy people.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: - Madam President, 92% of Madagascar's population lives on less than $ 2 a day. Madagascar is thus the poorest country in the world, but fortunately there is no armed conflict. Unfortunately, it is also an example of a country whose unstable political situation worsens the living conditions of the population and they further worsen political stability. Weak rule of law or restrictions on freedom of speech allow organized crime to mine illegally and damage Madagascar's unique nature. The destruction of nature makes it difficult to establish sustainable development in the local community and also leads to consequences such as the ongoing plague epidemic with already 127 dead. The World Health Organization sees a clear link between the overall poor social and political situation and the deterioration of health services, which has so far led to 1,800 cases of plague. Let us therefore call on the Government of Madagascar to guarantee respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, to ensure that democratic elections are held in 2018 and thus to create a space for a solution through dialogue and cooperation. If Madagascar does so, it can count on the help of the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Madagascar is facing a very difficult situation, having been hit hard by economic and political instability, by the negative growth of GDP and by the failure to meet the election deadlines. The failure of Madagascar to respect the election timeline has caused Western nations to withdraw financial aid and brought further political instability, worsening the country’s situation from the socio—economic, humanitarian and human rights perspectives. Therefore, in welcoming the call to devote attention to the preparations of the forthcoming presidential elections, I strongly believe that supervision from the international community’s side is required in order to ensure that democratic standards are met, and that elections take place in a free, open and transparent manner. Moreover, I conclude by expressing my full support for the call on the Malagasy authorities to fulfil their international commitments, to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms and, last but not least, to guarantee respect for the rule of law, which comes as a response to increasing concerns about human rights violations, arbitrary arrests and detentions, and about limited freedom of expression and unfair trials.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, it is interesting that at my own party’s national convention last week in Ireland prominence was given to the question of Africa and it was mentioned that the European Union as a whole, they felt, needed to engage more with Africa. I pointed out the lot of engagement we have already in terms of development and humanitarian aid, etc., but at the same time, it is a point worth making. Also worth making is the point made by my colleague behind me here, Cristian Dan Preda, that the delegations that went there were well—received and beneficial, and I think we need more direct dialogue – with Members of the European Parliament, with Commissioners, like Commissioner Hogan, etc. They can bring a lot of expertise and direction to countries like Madagascar and also help us better understand their problems and help them deal with issues like human rights violations and illegal logging, etc., and to ensure that their elections are properly conducted and fair. I think direct dialogue is something we need to encourage a bit more.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madagascar is experiencing a profound economic and political crisis which accentuates ancient problems that have never been resolved, first of all the situation of human rights, which is drastically deteriorating. A country among the most spectacular on the planet from an environmental point of view which is unable to exploit its resources due to continuous internal conflicts. In recent months, this instability has been joined by the outbreak of a worrying plague epidemic which has already registered 127 deaths. A dramatic situation, considering that 70% of the population still lives below the poverty line and that the health system has an average of only 3 beds for every 10,000 people. Madagascar remains one of the poorest nations in the world and its requests for help are often ignored by Western countries, little interested in the future of this large island in the Indian Ocean. The European Union must support human rights defenders in the country and work to ensure that the next democratic elections are held in an atmosphere of serenity and respect for the constitutional order.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I am taking this point on behalf of Vice-President Mogherini. She welcomes, of course, the interest of the House in the situation in Madagascar, which is entering a critical period in its history. It is important that we assess the political climate as we approach the presidential election, which is due a year from now.  Ensuring credible, inclusive and transparent elections has been mentioned by many Members in this House, and is a means of addressing a number of systemic issues, and doing so well before the electoral campaign itself has begun. Successful elections can only take place if citizens feel safe and secure, if candidates are free to run, if human rights and fundamental freedoms are demonstrably protected, and if the rule of law is maintained.  It is also important that the legislative framework for the elections should be prepared in an inclusive manner, both before and during passage through the parliamentary system. We are naturally concerned in the Commission about reports of violence and intimidation in Madagascar. These must be transparently investigated. Detention and harassment of journalists and civil society activists also cannot be ignored and is being followed up by our EU delegation in Antananarivo.  I want to assure Ms Kyenge that we continue to believe that Madagascar can enjoy a positive future if it can break the cycle of political crisis which has held back the development of resilient institutions and viable long-term reforms, which the country needs and which the EU is highly committed to supporting. There is urgent work to be done, as 90% of the population live on less than USD 2 per day and almost one in two children suffer from malnutrition. There is widespread social exclusion, and women and children are suffering in particular from exploitation. Health care and the environment are also critical priorities.  The challenges that are faced by human rights defenders and advocates of reform in Madagascar are complex and substantial. They stem from a culture of impunity which has allowed corruption to persist, but are exacerbated by specific issues such as disputes over land ownership and a lack of confidence in decentralised administration across this enormous and complex country. For ordinary people, difficulty in accessing information and in confronting a dysfunctional public administration leads to a sense of helplessness and encourages vigilante justice and other unacceptable means of conflict resolution.  Even when the European Union’s relations with Madagascar were constrained under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, we continued to maintain a strong partnership with civil society. Since the holding of democratic elections in 2013 and the restoration of constitutional order, we have fully resumed our cooperation, but we must recognise that the challenges faced by Madagascar can only be comprehensively addressed with stronger institutions and more accountability.  For Madagascar this is a critical period but also a period of opportunity. The Union will continue to encourage the progress which is needed in democratic consolidation. We recall the African Union Charter on Democracy, Elections and Governance, which sets out a clear democratic vision, including key elements for a successful election, such as strengthening of independent and impartial national electoral bodies, the maintenance of national mechanisms that redress election-related disputes, and ensuring fair and equitable access to state-controlled media during elections.  In relation to the action the European Union is taking on a regular basis, I would remind the House that our High Representative Ms Mogherini regularly raises these issues in relation to human rights, including Madagascar, and has raised them as recently as the Our Ocean Conference in Malta, or the last Donors Conference in Paris. These are where the concerns about human rights are raised by the EU’s highest level, as Mr Preda has acknowledged and has indicated. The EU is focusing all development and humanitarian aid on poverty reduction and is linking our budget support to human rights criteria.  Ms Charanzová and Mr Kelly have mentioned the importance of having free and fair elections. The European Union is focusing on financial support and technical support to the National Electoral Commission and to civil society, to assist in the organisation of these particular elections. Can I also say to Mr Kelly and to other Members that the support we are giving to Madagascar to have free and fair elections, in addition to the technical support, is a priority for the European Union in relation to electoral observation in 2018.  Next week we will have a very important occasion when the African Union and the European Union will be launching the External Investment Fund which has been proposed by Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission. I have regular contacts with the African Union Commissioner for Agriculture and we are working on developing technology transfer and vocational training and other development projects around how we can improve the position of women in agriculture – in particular in Africa and indeed in Madagascar – in order to get the benefits of the great cooperation of the EU and the African Union, but also to improve the lot of ordinary people through agriculture and food on the African continent, including Madagascar.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place today.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing.- Although the 2013 elections in Madagascar were held in a positive climate, with a democratic and credible outcome, the country's political, social and economic situation is still unstable.Journalists and human rights defenders enjoy very little freedom and are often victims of intimidation by national authorities.I believe that the European Union must support Madagascar to invest in the offer and support of human rights defenders and to ensure that we arrive at the 2018 elections in a climate of dialogue and credibility that can guarantee a fair and free electoral process.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Every state has a duty to create conditions for the full development of the population, to ensure compliance with fundamental human rights standards. The Malagasy authorities must uphold and protect the rights of their citizens. It is important to create a sustainable public administration apparatus, to take effective action for the purpose of stabilizing the political situation and the social and economic level. Effective action must be taken to prevent crime, violations of freedom of expression, terrorism and violence. The country must maintain its constitutional order and political stability. Peaceful resolution of conflicts must be ensured by providing the victims with the necessary medical, hygienic and food supplies, enabling a comprehensive supply of humanitarian aid. The Malagasy authorities must systematically carry out impartial investigations into extrajudicial executions, bring the perpetrators to justice and ensure that the families of the victims receive adequate compensation.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Dear Colleagues!The session has resumed.Mr Dartmouth, you raised a point of order.Please also say which article you are referring to.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I am rising under Rule 11(3). It is clear from the intervention of Ms Jacqueline Foster yesterday that Mr Corbett has misrepresented the role of Mr Verhofstadt in relation to the committee of Westminster MPs that visited Brussels re Brexit. It is a most serious matter to misrepresent... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Dear colleague!We cannot restart yesterday's discussion.I have another point of order.Mr. Woolfe, you have the floor!

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Madam President, I am grateful for permission to make this intervention. I rise in relation to two rules: Rule 184a and Rule 198. In relation to Rule 198, I seek that you, as the President, look to the House to form a committee that looks at the appalling and abysmal behaviour of Saudi Arabia towards the people of Yemen, and the funding of any projects of the European Union with Saudi Arabia.  As you are fully aware, the cholera crisis in Yemen is now reaching 1 million people. There are children dying daily in their hundreds and Saudi Arabia has decided to block the ports, the airports and any travel in, also not permitting people to treat those children. The European Union has a responsibility to deal with the suffering of those people in Yemen and I ask you under Rule 198 that this Parliament seeks to censure Saudi Arabia.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: May I ask you to come to your point of order?That's not the case.OK.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, yesterday a deadly flood in my country, Greece, in the western suburbs of Athens, caused a huge natural disaster and we are already mourning 15 dead.Given the expression of solidarity of the European Parliament and of the whole of the European Union to the Greek people affected by this catastrophe, and as an expression of condolences to the families of the dead, I suggest, Madam President, that there be a minute's silence.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank-you.Unfortunately, we cannot observe such a minute's silence today, but one thing is very clear: we are all among the victims of disasters, which for us are really always very great human catastrophes.Thank you, Mr Papadimoulis, and thank you for thinking of the victims.I thank you for the fact that we always stand up for minorities and that we ensure that they are protected.That is a very important question for us as the European Parliament.Thank you for informing us about it again.But if you will allow me, I would now like to turn to our Rules of Procedure.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: - Madam President!I wanted to inform the plenary that on Tuesday afternoon, during the debate on the rule of law in Malta, the livestream transmission in Malta was disrupted after Mr Giegold's contribution and switched off after Mr Casa’s contribution.A total of 28 colleagues who spoke afterwards were unable to speak.I think this is a huge scandal and I ask the Bureau to investigate the cause.(Applause)

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you for the information.However, I do not see any further procedural motions now.That is why we come to our work.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item is voting time.(Voting results and other details of the voting: see Minutes.)

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - A point of order, Madam President, to make a protest.It is noon and ten, the document that we are now going to vote on, although it is only an expression of your consent, is only available in one language of this house, when the document dates from the 6th of November.This is a violation of the principle of multilingualism which limits the ability of Members of this House to evaluate the document in question in their own language and which should prevent voting on any document, this or another, under these conditions.It will, of course, be the result of what budget cuts are in terms of translation, and we have to file this protest.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Mr Pimenta Lopes!We are not voting today on the report as such, but only on the LIBE committee's decision to start negotiations.According to our rules of procedure, no translation of the report into all official languages is required for negotiations to begin.The report has been available in English since last week.This is the usual trialogue procedure.The translation will be submitted later.We now come to the vote on the decision of the LIBE committee on the basis of Mrs Wikström's report.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, the European Parliament has managed to do something quite unusual: we have united the EPP, the Socialist Group, the ALDE Group, the Greens and the GUE Group to build a solid reform of the Dublin Regulation, based on solidarity. It is a complicated, delicate file, but according to the Eurobarometer of this year 70% of citizens of Europe expect the European Union to deliver on this, to deliver on the collapsed system that we have today.  It is high time today that we deliver. United we are strong. The alternative is that we stand, as of today, with no policy on a very topical and very difficult area, namely migration. If we cannot manage to unite, the European Parliament makes itself completely irrelevant. If we are united we can also ask the Council to come up with a position where they can unite. We have united, more than 200 political parties of Europe, on this, and a big majority of the Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) Committee.  Now the Council does not even have a position. We have a position that will change the reality out there, so, colleagues, today I stand before you asking for your confidence to start negotiations based on solidarity, based on European policy, creating an asylum system that is going to change the chaos of today and turn it into order. The alternative we know very well. It is your choice. Ask me, together with my team, to enter into negotiations, or defend the failed policy as of today in front of your citizens, if you can.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Sorry.Thank you Ms. Wikström.Mr Pimenta has already given the counter-speech.That is why we can now go to the vote.The committee's decision was approved by Parliament.Negotiations can be started at any time.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Madam President, of course I supported this report and I can only express my joy that, after a certain pause, the European Parliament is working to develop relations with the Pacific region, not only with New Zealand but also with Australia.After all, last year we gave a mandate here to negotiate a free trade agreement with both Australia and New Zealand, and today's vote on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and relations with New Zealand is a very good way forward, so it is good thatThe European Union is opening a partnership window on the trade route to this region, and I think there has been and will be a very broad consensus here that this is a good thing, that it is to the benefit of our national economies and that we should continue to do so.Let's definitely support it.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I also support the partnership and relations agreement between the European Union and New Zealand.It is a promising step in gaining an important business and strategic partner and ally in the Asia-Pacific region.Since deepening relations with New Zealand, I personally promise to promote sustainable investment and growth, the creation of new jobs on both sides and also new business opportunities for private entities.And, among other things, cooperation in many areas: from innovation, science to migration, terrorism, the fight against organized crime, cybercrime or judicial cooperation.In my opinion, New Zealand is an important player in the European Union's trade strategy in this area, and deeper and balanced effective cooperation will help mutual satisfaction and stable democracy.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, what an amazing country New Zealand is: 4 million people, as remote geographically as any territory in the world, totally dependent on international trade, and yet it has gone a quarter of a century without a single quarter of negative economic growth. How? By international global commerce.  Yet, here is the amazing thing: no one in New Zealand is suggesting that in order to succeed they need to join a customs union with Malaysia or join a political union with Nauru, or even join a single currency with Australia. They have managed to succeed by living under their own laws, while remaining interested and engaged in the affairs of every country on every continent. It is a natural healthy thing to be independent and to trade. Commerce does not require political union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I was very pleased to vote in favour of this report, and very much welcome the signing of the partnership agreement with New Zealand. It is testament to the ongoing cooperation that the EU has fostered with New Zealand. The agreement has reinforced cooperation on a wide variety of important areas, and also facilitates further progress in trade with the launching of negotiations for the free trade agreement between the EU and New Zealand. Speaking as an Irish person, we have a long-standing, friendly relationship with New Zealand. Indeed, one in six New Zealanders claim Irish heritage, and the Irish Government was very pleased to witness the opening of the New Zealand embassy in Dublin earlier this year. There have always been strong personal and cultural links between the two countries. This is also the case for other Member States, and certainly now for the European Union at large. The PARC Agreement has built on political, economic and cultural ties that look forward to future developments between the EU and New Zealand in these areas and of course, as the world gets smaller, New Zealand comes nearer to us.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this agreement because I firmly believe that this cooperation will be fruitful, allowing both partners to swiftly move towards a modern, comprehensive and fair free trade agreement. I recognise the importance of New Zealand for my country, Sweden. It is actually the eighth most important trade partner for my country, and I believe it can be so with the EU as well. I believe that this agreement is especially important in this protectionist time as a fight against protectionism, and that is why I supported it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of this report because the European Union and its Member States and New Zealand have a healthy and good relationship, while sharing many common goals on most global issues, such as democracy, the rule of law and human rights. the fight against climate terrorism. They are also active supporters and participants in multilateral organizations, such as the United Nations and the World Trade Organization. Relations between the two partner countries were strengthened in October 2016 with the signing of the Partnership Agreement between the European Union and New Zealand, which will provide a comprehensive and modern legal basis for relations between the two negotiating parties. The aim is to facilitate more effective bilateral engagement by the Union and its Member States with New Zealand by strengthening political dialogue, improving cooperation on economic and trade issues and many other areas of innovation, education, culture and migration. That is why I supported the resolution and the conclusion of the partnership agreement.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, if we want to help Europe, we must help Africa. This must be our strategy for the coming months and years. That is why I supported the report, which contains a number of specific recommendations for the forthcoming EU-Africa summit. Over the last 30 years, Africa's population has doubled from 600 million to 1.2 billion and will continue to grow. Of course, as the population grows, so will the migratory pressure. The European Union is the largest provider of development aid. But we must also combine values ​​with economic aid, especially the protection of human rights, the dignity of life and the rule of law. In addition to armed conflict, political repression and a poor economic situation, climate change is also the reason for migration. We need conditions in Africa to improve and people to have dignified conditions and motivation to grow. Finally, let me recall the words of Pope Francis. Behind all the numbers, we must see people, a specific person, and that must be our human strategy.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the partnership with Africa must reflect new priorities that copy the political and economic development of both continents.The partnership has several priority areas: from economic cooperation, through migration and the environment.I would emphasize two - from my point of view - the most important areas of the strategy.Firstly, there is respect for human rights, which are highly violated on the African continent, and security throughout the continent.In the context of the recent events in Madagascar and other African countries, I would like to appeal for the European Union's active participation in respect for human rights across Africa.That's why I supported it.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I supported Mr Ponga's report for a number of reasons. First of all, Africa is one of Europe's main economic partners in economic and trade terms, and not only because of that, but also when it comes to the development of humanitarian aid. Strengthening the political dialogue between the European Union and Africa is a precondition for renewing the strategic partnership in order to deliver benefits in the various areas of economic development, growth, job creation, migration and security. To this end, the development of a regional dimension of cooperation between the African continent and the European Union would be essential. The report also highlights and calls for a strategy on the most important issue, mobility and migration, which will contribute to the development of both Africa and the Union. This is an extremely important element in view of the ongoing migration flow from North and Central Africa. Undoubtedly, such a strategy is needed, and Europe must focus its efforts on stabilizing these countries in order to prevent the migration crisis from deepening.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, support for the African continent is not a gift or charity. Investment in Africa’s development will help not only the African people, but also us Europeans. A stable and developing African continent will give us more security. It will prevent forced migration, because people will be able to receive decent work and social protection in their states and native lands. It will give us more possibilities for our businesses to find partners and of course new markets. In my view, there are a lot of empty words from the leaders of our EU Member States that mask a lack of will. The test will be whether or not the Member States of the European Union fulfil their commitment to directing 0.7% of their GDP to official development assistance to strengthen cooperation with Africa.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Mrs. D'Amato!You have registered two minutes, both for Mrs Mizzi's report and for Mr López's report.You only have three minutes in total.Could you tell me which of the two reports the two minutes are for and which other the one minute is for, so that I have it for my record?

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Ombudsman's report demonstrates a work that has been carried out with attention to citizens' rights in relation to the European institutions, starting with the commitment to greater transparency and better access to documents. Emphasis was placed on the need to apply stricter ethical standards for Union politicians and staff, so as to ensure the integrity, discretion and full independence of the private sector, without dangerous interconnections or conflicts of interest. It is therefore essential that the Ombudsman pursues his path to ensure the publication of the names of those officials or politicians who have taken advantage of the so-called revolving doors, rapidly moving from an institutional role to a private management or vice versa. How not to mention the bad example provided by former Commission President Barroso, who took up a presidential position at Goldman Sachs. Despite having respected the 18-month limit, the Ombudsman highlighted that this time frame is too short and needs to be urgently reviewed to safeguard the duties of honesty and delicacy that are imposed by this function. Another relevant case is the Commission's attitude in meetings with tobacco lobbies, for which greater transparency was requested. The Commission has not given valid reasons for refusing to carry out the recommendations and is therefore a crime of maladministration. The European Central Bank is also under the lens, which must make public some parts of the single supervisory mechanism, in addition to the letters sent to banks and institutions under supervision. It is therefore a first breach in the impenetrable wall of the ECB that would allow citizens to look through the peephole of the door, awaiting further courageous initiatives that would allow the structures to be made transparent. economic and banking activities.Citizens perceive the Union with a distant and impenetrable structure.The Ombudsman's efforts must continue with the same intensity and unravel the shadows surrounding the European institutions.For this reason, our vote was positive.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by highlighting the work of the European Ombudsman, who is one of the independent checks on the proper functioning of the European Union.In the name of transparency, democracy and openness in the European Union, it is an important authority that helps individuals to protect their rights.It is clear that this institution makes sense and is doing well, as in 2016 almost 16,000 people turned to the office for help.Yes, I'm not wrong.What I must point out, however, is that of this number, less than 2,000 applications were considered to be a complaint falling within the competence of the European Ombudsman.Therefore, it is necessary to further show what the competence of the European Ombudsman is and thus increase people's awareness.I think it would be appropriate to raise awareness of the Office and also to support the Ombudsman's own work.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the European Ombudsman has the very important function of improving the quality or work of the European institutions. Let’s be frank, very often we can see examples of lack of transparency, conflicts of interest and red tape. Each such case discredits the idea of the European Union and gives strong arguments to the numerous Eurosceptics.  Ombudsmen should pay more attention to the revolving-door phenomenon in the European Union. Ombudsmen should insist on the creation of an independent ethics board which would decide which professional activities are subject to a conflict of interest. Ombudsmen should play a bigger role in order to make the European institutions more open, transparent and more understandable for Europeans. We should remember that it is very easy to lose the trust of people, but it is very hard to restore it. Of course, I voted in favour.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
