name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the divergences in terms of income, employment and opportunities, which have been emphasized with the economic-financial crisis, are evident and mortify the existence of people, since economic security is important for the fulfillment of citizens and for their general well-being. Today it is not enough simply to have a job to be protected from poverty, because various atypical types of contracts, many unpaid internships, different forms of unconventional or unreported employment, such as slavery by the gangster, impose economic conditions at the limit, if not at the limit. below the poverty line. Inequalities create discouragement, bring discontent and anger, create a humus that feeds instability and distrust in the European Union. Yet they have been fed by the recipe for austerity and the country-specific recommendations that Europe has decided to lump its citizens. Unemployment, cuts in wages and pensions as well as welfare have undermined the lives of many people, and all in the face of the priority of the well-being of peoples recognized in the European treaties. The answers, therefore, should not be sought in specific recommendations or in the European Semester, one cannot think of healing a sick person with the same medicines that made him agonized. If we do not change the yardstick with which the tailor makes the suit, as long as everything is calibrated on the gross domestic product, we will find ourselves struggling with tight and suffocating clothes. When we adopt parameters that take into account social progress and the real well-being of citizens, then we will be able to see measures capable of guaranteeing employment and fair wages. An authentic European pillar of social rights is welcome, action to balance professional and private life is welcome, but other solutions proposed by the rapporteur are not adequate and for this we abstained.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report, especially the section on helping people with disabilities achieve secure employment. Four years ago, when Norwich’s Remploy factory shut, the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) said that funding should be focused on helping disabled people into mainstream jobs, but where is that funding now? The replacement for the DWP’s work program has seen its funding slashed by three-quarters. The British Government has gone back on its word.  Remploy did as was asked and today helps people with disabilities find and keep mainstream jobs. What they do worked. When I spoke to them they told me about Milo, who secured a full-time job working on Cromer Pier, and Brandon, who said it is thanks to Remploy that he now feels that he has a future. But now Remploy in Norwich is set to close, and experienced employment coaches will lose their jobs. The British Government talks warm words about helping disabled people into work, but is high time that they put their money where their mouth is.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted against this report because, despite some of the positive proposals contained in it, it does not take into account one of the main differences for the European Union - the income gap between the so-called 'old Europe', or the western part of the European Union, and Central and Eastern Europe, or the new members. This huge difference in income and pay motivates many young people in Eastern Europe to leave their homelands and move west, thus causing a demographic crisis in their countries. And this large income gap is largely due to the protectionist measures that some governments in this part of Europe are taking and implementing. Protectionist measures aimed at preventing them from entering the labor market, preventing entrepreneurs from working, earning their money, being able to pay good wages in Eastern Europe and young people staying at home instead of traveling somewhere. west. That is why I voted against.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we often try to solve a problem only when it becomes evident, but very often it is hard to find a good solution at this stage. Inequality starts in childhood. Different possibilities in education and health services for one group of children than for another start to create an equality gap. As people become older, accumulated inequality starts to give negative results in people’s work and social life. That is why it is so important to make a timely investment in children’s and young people’s education, skills and health. One of the positive examples of such a programme is the Youth Employment Initiative. This programme shows positive results. It needs a higher funding level for the period 2017-2020, at least EUR 21 billion. Every additional euro spent on these purposes will be returned to society by people who will be integrated into society and fully realise their talents. I voted in favour.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Madam President, social inequalities have become even more pronounced after the severe economic crisis of the last decade. The gap between rich and poor has widened not only between Member States but also between them. The direct victims were young people and low-skilled workers. We cannot afford the future young generation to live worse than us. Poverty and lack of opportunities for professional realization drove more than 16,000 young and educated Bulgarians out of Bulgaria in 2016 alone. We are now talking about the depopulation of certain regions. In time, at this rate, we will be talking about the depopulation of all of Eastern Europe. This new reality also implies a new type of attitude to the problem. Stagnation in cohesion policy at European level cannot stop migration from east to west. I am not sure that the prioritization of investments in infrastructure projects will force Bulgarians abroad to return to their homeland.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótálas i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar is dóigh liom go bhfuil cothromaíocht thar a bheith tábhachtach don Aontas. and combating equality should take the form of a variety of mechanisms – support for employees, digitisation of the workplace, addressing the gender pay gap, reinforcing efforts to eliminate poverty and enhanced employment policies affecting young people. Inequality resulting from the economic crisis had a particularly negative effect on women, causing increased exclusion from the labour market and worsening poverty among women. name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! One of the five goals of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million. Taking into account that after the crisis there were 1.7 million more such people than in 2008, we can conclude that the actions taken do not bring the expected results. Too high and growing inequalities not only have direct social costs, but can also act as an obstacle to economic growth. Reducing inequalities must be one of the top institutional priorities at European level. This is a prerequisite for economic recovery, job creation, increased social cohesion and shared prosperity. The Union's activity cannot, however, replace the Member States' own efforts, primarily in the area of ​​the labor market. The best instrument to combat poverty is job creation and equal opportunities at the national or regional level. Therefore, any solution that transfers responsibility to the Union level should be opposed, as this breaches the subsidiarity principle and only contributes to perpetuating the problem, not solving it, which is why I abstained on voting on the report.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I want to make it clear from the outset that this report is a first step. However, it does not solve the inequality and the problems we have identified, child poverty, gender inequality, low incomes in certain areas, especially in rural areas. I think that from now on the Commission has great problems in correlating this project and I am very happy. I voted for him, I supported him with the group I belong to. I am in my country in a humanist party. We can't help but think of people. But the Commission needs to correlate because cohesion funds have not yet achieved their goal. We must continue to allocate cohesion funds to a higher percentage and especially to poor areas. There are children who are born poor, remain poor, raise poor families, have no access to school, no access to education, no access to health. This is a very complex issue and, of course, it is good that the social pillar was included in the European Semester, but I believe that we need to deal systemically and the Commission needs to deal systemically in conjunction with other resolutions and other directives and regulations.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on an oral question to the Commission by Petra Kammerevert, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on 2018: The EU-China Tourism Year (O-000071/2017 - B8-0609 / 2017) (2017/2846(RSP)).

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: representing the author. - Mr President, Commissioner, I have the honor to present, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, an oral question to the Commission on the European Union-China Tourism Year for the following year 2018. I was the initiator of this question and I am glad that it was supported by all factions in our committee. We have a common concern. In 2016, at a meeting with Chinese Prime Minister Li Kichiang, the Commission and its President Juncker decided that 2018 would be the year of tourism between the EU and China. They did so without consulting the European Parliament. We did not have the opportunity to get acquainted with the content and conditions of this project. At the same time, it was the CULT committee and, subsequently, the entire European Parliament that came up with the initiative in 2016 to make 2018 the European Year of Cultural Heritage. We have serious reasons and expectations for this. The European Union is experiencing a period of rising populism, radicalism and division. That is why we want to return to the roots of European civilization. We want to remind the younger generation in particular that we are living in a historically unprecedented period of peace, freedom and prosperity. All this has been redeemed by millions of human victims. That is why we can safely enjoy the cultural richness that has always united us. The aim of the European Year of Cultural Heritage is therefore primarily to promote European values ​​and strengthen our belonging. We are therefore right to ask, what is the aim of the EU-China tourism year? Our questions are: 1. Can the Commission explain why it is so important for Europe that the EU-China Year of Tourism take place in the same year as the European Year of Cultural Heritage? 2. How will the Commission manage both initiatives at the same time? 3. How does the Commission plan to create synergies between the two activities? 4. How does the Commission intend to ensure sufficient visibility for both activities? From these questions, it is clear what we are talking about. It is simply not clear to us how both events will be managed and promoted so that, in particular, the European Cultural Heritage Year is not weakened. From our point of view, these are more activities disparate and competing with each other. We are interested in why the Commission has decided to address this thematic and financial fragmentation of cultural initiatives. In the case of the Year of Tourism, the Commission is approaching China in an area that is developing very intensively even without public support. At the same time, the Commission is planning to spend EUR 8 million on a common promotion platform. We are interested in whether this is the final number or whether it has promised some more funding. Tourism between the Member States and China is developing very fast and there is no need to support it from the European level, especially not financially. Even without this support, almost 11 million tourists from China visited the European Union last year. I ask myself: how can we promote European values ​​if we work with China at the same time without any human rights conditions? I would like to remind you that there are still almost 1,500 political prisoners in China and the human and social rights of tens of millions of people are being massively violated. In connection with our Monday debate on the persecution of Christians, I would like to add that if the Chinese want to visit Christian monuments in Europe as tourists, they must stop persecuting Christians as well as other religious minorities at home. This should be the Commission's starting position for similar initiatives in relation to China. From a professional point of view, the question arises as to whether mass tourism is in any way particularly beneficial for the preservation of cultural monuments. I would have my doubts about that. This is true for many places in Europe that are facing congestion from the influx of tourists, but it is also true, for example, for Tibet under Chinese administration, where mass tourism from the West, supported by the Chinese, has a rather destructive effect on local culture. I have tried to raise here the main questions that concern us in this regard, and I hope that the Commission will answer them. The committee will, of course, assist us in finding a positive solution. And finally a request. Please do not suspect us of being against cooperation. Certainly not. But we want to make it clear that the values human rights and freedoms are part of our European policy and are not for sale.Thank you for your attention and I look forward to hearing from you, Commissioner.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am taking this point on behalf of Commissioner Bieńkowska. I would like to thank the honourable Member for the question on the 2018 EU—China Tourism Year and its relationship with the European Year of Cultural Heritage. As you know, these two initiatives are very important for the Commission. We decided to have the tourism year with China in 2018 following the 2016 US—China Year and the 2017 Australia—China Year, and the reason is clear. These countries are our immediate competitors in this particular region, and in the tourism sector in particular. We needed to match their efforts to attract Chinese travellers. The Tourism Year is also a unique opportunity to restore the image of the European Union as a tourism destination in the face of growing global competition from other markets. The two Years are pursuing different, but complementary, policy objectives. The main objective of the European Year of Cultural Heritage is the promotion and preservation of Europe’s cultural heritage and the values it embodies. The main objective of the EU-China Tourism Year is jobs and growth. The EU-China Tourism Year aims to attract more of the most desirable Chinese travellers. I am talking about those with high revenues, travelling off—season, not only to famous, but also to lesser—known, places. Overall, both Years contribute to developing sustainable cultural tourism. They make us consider how to preserve our heritage and help us find ways to finance its preservation in a sustainable manner.  Managing the two initiatives in parallel will not be a problem. The Commission services are coordinating our efforts to make sure that everything will go according to schedule. In addition, right from the start we have been working together intensively within the Commission, and I would like to give you one example. Under the European Year of Cultural Heritage, UNESCO was asked to develop four thematic itineraries between lesser—known world heritage sites in the European Union in order to attract tourists in a sustainable way, but it was also asked to conceive them for Chinese travellers especially and to promote them in China under the logo of the EU—China Tourism Year.  The two initiatives have dedicated budgets and will be advertised through separate means, targeting different audiences. This budget is EUR 4.3 million, not EUR 8 million. In the case of the EU—China Tourism Year, we have mainly targeted the EU travel and tourism industry. We will use business-to-business events to point to opportunities and ways to be more China-ready. In China, we are targeting a wider audience in addition to Chinese tour operators, thanks to events attracting the attention of the Chinese mass media. The 2018 European Year of Cultural Heritage targets the wider European public with a specific focus on young people between 15 and 25 years old.  So the two Years are pursuing different policy goals and targeting different groups, but there are complementarities and synergies on which we can build and we are making sure that these synergies are exploited. I want  to assure the Member that this is the way in which we are proceeding and to inform the House that Commissioner Navracsics, the relevant Commissioner, has been in China in the past few days, making sure that the issues that are rightly addressed by the Member are being addressed and that complementarity is being achieved.

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to pass on to you my colleague, Mr Sógor’s, apologies. He had to leave earlier on because of the strike in France. I will now read his statement. I think that at least once or twice in our lives many of us have already been confronted with the question of whether travelling to a country where human rights are violated is ethical or not. I believe that, as in most issues, it is the scale and the severity of the violation that matters. Even though many countries across the globe are far from perfect in this regard, China still stands out, but even in China there are regions that stand out.  Let us take the case of Tibet, which is at the rock—bottom of the freedom ranking list of Freedom House, a place where civil and political rights are non-existent. Now let us suppose that Tibet for a while is not closed to foreign tourists, let us suppose that with your passport – something that most Tibetans are not allowed to have – you can visit the region. Let us suppose that, as a foreigner, you can get past through police road checks and you can enter Lhasa, a city which ordinary Tibetans from outside the city are restricted to access.  You would find yourself in a place where draconian surveillance measures are implemented to enforce the so-called ‘stability’ of the region; where detentions, prosecutions and convictions of Tibetans for the peaceful exercise of their freedoms of expression, assembly and religious belief are carried out in alarming numbers; where many Tibetans set themselves on fire because they are denied their basic fundamental rights; or where state policies encourage migration from other parts of China in order to reduce the ethnic Tibetan share of the population. In the light of this, I firmly believe that the conclusion of a tourism agreement with China, without a single human rights reference, is not ethical, nor is it in line with our universal and foreign policy values.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Mr Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the question thus posed, which we are now discussing, should be answered as follows: the two initiatives must in no way oppose or collide. Is there any interest in the European Year of Culture? Yes of course. Is there any interest in tourism in the European Union on the part of the citizens of the People's Republic of China? Yes of course. But when we start raising the issue of internal order in China, let's not be hypocritical then and ask: do European countries trade, say, with Saudi Arabia? Are human rights being violated in Saudi Arabia? I say yes. Just to remind the petitioner and other colleagues that public executions are taking place in the square with a sword in Saudi Arabia. People's heads are cut off. But companies from European Union countries sell and trade with Saudi Arabia. What is this - hypocrisy, double standard? How exactly do we determine which country is bad, which is not bad, and where do we put the label for the protection of human rights? After all, there is an international legal order. There are a number of states that form the international legal order. Among them are China, among them is Saudi Arabia, Turkey. Are we trading with Turkey? We trade. Is there a violation of human rights in Turkey? To have. Do their colleagues protect them? They protect them. So where is the middle section then? And where then do we determine which country violates human rights the most and which does not? I claim that we have an interest in representing European countries in China. There is interest from Chinese tourists in European countries. Moreover, there is interest in the development of trade. Because trade, tourism, the economy are prosperity and provide opportunities for greater development, better living standards, prosperity and profits. And that is why I think that this hall is not a place where we have to measure with different standards where human rights are violated more.

name: Andrejs Mamikins
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in my view, if we want to place the accent on one theme one year, it would be logical not to devalue it by creating another similar theme the next year. Such a policy could lead to the absurd ‘Year of Everything’. In my opinion, that is not our aim. I understand that the EU—China Tourism Year is very important for the Commission in order to create better relations with China, but it could be better implemented in another form. I hope that in the future this consideration will be taken into account.

name: Yana Toom
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Europe is famous for its cultural pluralism and openness. Cultural ties with China are based on good political and economic relations. In the case of China, the link between tourism and cultural interests is obvious. Therefore the idea of carrying out the EU—China Tourism Year is welcomed.  Should the EU-China Tourism Year and the European Year of Cultural Heritage coincide in time? I believe that this is possible in so far as the Commission can ensure their adequate organisation. Although both initiatives are related to culture, their content will be different. In addition, the synergy between these activities is possible and desirable.  China and the EU are regional and world leaders with ancient cultural traditions that can mutually enrich our people. So I do not think that the EU-China Tourism Year can somehow prevent the promotion of European identity and values. Our similarities and our differences will be much more visible against the backdrop of our Asian partner.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue.- Thank you very much, Mrs Toom, for accepting my blue card question.This week, here in the European Parliament - in fact yesterday - we celebrated the centenary of the Bolshevik revolution, and several colleagues condemned the communist regime, the communist party and so on.And at the same time, here in Parliament, we want to be friends with China, a country with 1.5 billion people led by the Communist Party.Don't you think it's somewhat hypocritical?Thanks!

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for the question. You know I spoke about this yesterday. For me it is a bit hypocritical. Yesterday, I reminded my colleagues that we have representatives of eight communist parties here and that we have pretty good relations with China’s communist regime.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, there is a deep irony in the fact that the EU-China Tourism Year and the European Year of Cultural Heritage will both take place next year. We will celebrate and promote European cultural diversity, while at the same time working to improve opportunities to increase economic cooperation, in the words of the European Commission, with a regime that represses such diversity in its own territory, often with the utmost brutality and with a blatant disregard for human rights. I am thinking particularly of Tibet, where culture and religion have been the target of relentless oppression at the same time as their remnants are being used to boost Chinese tourism. We should not forget that while Tibetans themselves are not permitted to travel freely and while many Tibetans live in extreme poverty, the Chinese state-sponsored tourism industry reaps the benefits of the appropriation of Tibetan culture and history. In fact, Tibetans are rarely employed by this industry and are not even required to give their consent to huge infrastructure projects aimed at boosting tourism.  I have never been to China but it is clearly a diverse, rich and fascinating country. Neither have I visited Tibet, although what I have learned about the country and its culture through my work in the European Parliament is compelling. My own choice would be to avoid visiting an occupied country that is being deprived of its right to self-determination and I would urge others to follow this policy.  Much closer to home, in July this year Liverpool FC signed a controversial sponsorship deal with Tibet Water Resources Limited that exploits the natural resources of Tibet to the detriment of the local population and the environment. Such commercial agreements not only lend legitimacy to China’s occupation of Tibet but are, in fact, only possible because of it. This sponsorship deal puts the club and the city of Liverpool at the centre of China’s on-going occupation of Tibet. I know that this does not reflect the views of either the fans or the city, and I urge the club to reconsider this misguided and ill-considered deal. We also need to consider whether this is the kind of reckless international economic cooperation that we want to promote as EU institutions.  The unfortunate timing of the EU-China Tourism Year sends a signal that economic interests are once again being prioritised over human rights.  In concluding, I urge the Commission to put human rights firmly on the agenda with our international partners, for example by calling on Beijing to restart talks with the representatives of His Holiness the Dalai Lama that have been stalled since 2010.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam Member, I acknowledge your speech and the emphasis on human rights, but I would like to ask you very pragmatically and without any irony or sarcasm.I would like to ask: How would you handle this situation?How would you deal with relations with China today, what would you prefer?Do you think that we should somehow reconsider, for example, economic relations with China?How should we approach this year?

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for that question. I have a very pragmatic response which is to say that the Commission, when negotiating trade deals and when thinking about its economic partnerships, should place human rights and high social and environmental standards right at the heart. A good way to do that will be to support the binding Human Rights Charter for global corporations, which is currently being negotiated by the UN. Unfortunately, the EU has sided with the USA and with the corporations in not supporting that binding charter, but that is a very practical way in which we can defend human rights through our economic partnerships and through our trade policy.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, is dóigh liom go bhfuil moladh tuillte ag Feisire Sojdrova as ucht an cheist a chur ar an gCoimisiún agus an t-ábhar seo a chur ar an gclár anseo inniu. Ach d’fhreagair, ar son an Choimisiúin, an tUasal Ó hÓgáin í agus b’fhéidir nach bhfuil sé idéalach, ach is ceart dúinn glacadh leis agus bualadh ar aghaidh chun an dá rud a chur chun cinn, is é sin Aontas Sóirte, an tSín agus an tAontas agus Bliain Chultúrtha na hEorpa. So the Commissioner’s answer, I think, will suffice. We have an opportunity to promote culture, and I know I come from a country with a rich cultural heritage: our language,  Bíonn seans agam í a labhairt sa Pharlaimint anseo. our games, our music, our dance, our literature. I think the European Year of Culture will give us a great opportunity to promote that, as well as for other Member States. The synergies involved will actually help us to grow both an appreciation of our culture and also the jobs etc. associated with it.  But that does not mean we cannot promote the year of EU-China tourism as well. China is the second-largest travelling group in the world in terms of tourism. They have a huge expenditure of EUR 1.4 billion, and in my own country last year 60 000 Chinese came to visit us. So of course we should have a promotion of EU-China tourism.  Also , while I agree completely that human rights is a major issue – we just spent two hours discussing human rights issues this morning – you cannot say, on the one hand: because we are not happy with your human rights record we are not going to have any business with you; and, on the other hand, say: because Donald Trump pulled out of the climate change and now you have taken leadership, we are delighted with you and we are going to cooperate with you. So these are all issues to be taken in tandem, but I definitely think that these two can work together, as the Commissioner said, and I think it is going to be good for everybody.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I believe that establishing the Year of Tourism between the European Union and China is a great opportunity for our Europe. Furthermore, 2018 itself will also be the European Year of Cultural Heritage. The combination of these two important initiatives represents an opportunity for growth and wealth for Europe in terms of economic development and employment, two priorities of the European Union. Despite the economic crisis, tourism is one of the sectors that has experienced the greatest growth worldwide in the last ten years and is the third largest economic activity in Europe after trade and the construction sector. Its impact on gross domestic product reaches 10% if indirectly related activities are also calculated. However, it must be borne in mind that this is an extremely vulnerable and above all constantly evolving sector. With regard to vulnerability, the demographic aspect must be taken into account, as tourists are older than in past decades. As regards the evolution, however, we find the arrival of tourists from emerging countries such as China. Tourism also plays a key role in boosting growth in many sectors such as transport. The new silk road, which connects our continent to the Asian one, is of vital importance to bring different cultures together and facilitate cultural exchanges. Europe is today the first world tourist destination for its natural, scenic and cultural beauties, but to maintain the primacy it is necessary to start adequate development policies. Fundamental in this process is the liberalization of tourist visas. Furthermore, both Europe and China must aim at improving the tourist experience, enhancing lesser-known and more sustainable destinations, thus obviating the problem of mass tourism. They are therefore vitally good air connections between the two continents, but above all internal.In fact, they will lead tourists to discover not the classic destinations but also to explore unusual places.Cultural diversity, wealth and history of the European Union are not found only in the European capitals, but in all destinations, even the most remote.Reaching these locations, also thanks to digitalization, will help the territories to find economic sustainability, avoid depopulation and ease the influx of tourists in overly crowded destinations.The two initiatives that will take place simultaneously in 2018 can generate complications.I therefore hope that the Commission will be able to find a common roadmap and create synergies.Finally, I am very proud of the fact that both initiatives take place in my country, Italy.In fact, the inauguration of the European Year of Cultural Heritage will be held in Milan and that of the Year of Tourism in Venice.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! I share the author's doubts about combining the celebration of European cultural heritage - which is of great importance for the history of European cultural wealth - with the proclamation of the year of tourism between the EU and China, which of course is of great value, as well as trade and economic contacts. However, the Union should persuade China not only to protect the environment but to uphold universal values ​​such as human rights, which are still violated in China, where in recent years there has been an increase in the persecution of Christians with the demolition of churches, the removal of the cross, and the arrest of believers and priests. Moreover, for many years, despite the adoption of various resolutions from around the world, including the European Parliament, the United States, Australia, Israel and Canada, there is still a large-scale trafficking in human organs taken from the killed prisoners along with profits from this practice. Money or tourism cannot take precedence over human life and its dignity.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I am a little surprised by the logic of this issue, I must say. A large part of us here lived in communist countries, and we loved to travel and we loved tourism, and that’s why I’m a little surprised that we call out China for their regime. We are talking about tourism here, my people. I had the honor of leading Istria, the most tourist region in Croatia, and I know what tourism means for our citizens. So let's encourage tourism from China as well. I think it’s a great initiative and even related to the year of culture that is also being prepared for next year. One thing we need to know. Dates for Chinese tourists are great for us, especially in the Mediterranean, because they mostly travel in the post-season and pre-season, because such are their dates when they go on vacation. And last but not least, this proves what I keep saying, we need a European Union tourism agency. We need to institutionalize what brings 10% of the gross domestic product of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Thank you for accepting the question.I pointed out that 11 million Chinese tourists came to Europe last year, in 2016.Do you think that is not enough?Do you think we need to do a lot of European publicity?No one wants to prevent agencies from promoting tourism from driving tourists.We certainly do not want to prevent this, but if Europe gives support to something, then it should be linked to the promotion of its European values.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: the answer to the question posed by raising the blue card.- Dear Ms. Shoydrova, thank you for your question.I think the complete opposite of you.I think that the European Union should institutionalize tourism, as I said, we should have a tourism agency when we already have so many agencies because tourism brings 10% of the gross domestic product of the European Union.That's an awful lot of money.And yes, we need more tourists from China.Yes, we need it.I explained to you before.Maybe you didn't know that detail.For Mediterranean tourism, Chinese tourists are ideal because they come in the pre-season and in the post-season.I've said that before.When we want tourists, they simply wanted to be there, let's fill them up, even with friends from China.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I certainly welcome this initiative for several reasons. It is important that there is not only an economic but also a cultural exchange between the European Union and China. This platform will not only help the already mentioned tourism in lesser-known areas and help small and medium-sized enterprises, but can also bring together various institutions that would not otherwise meet. Universities, representatives of the private sector, can also bring together people who will work here in the future. At the same time, it will increase the experience and qualifications of people working in the tourism sector. Like it or not, China is and will continue to be an important strategic partner of the European Union, and it is important to realize that this initiative is also very important for the European Union in understanding how the Chinese market will behave in the future. And this certainly does not diminish the European Union's emphasis on the various rights of Chinese citizens, and I do not think that the call for the Republic of China to respect the human rights of all Chinese citizens is in any way undermined.

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, the European Year of Cultural Heritage and the joint Euro-Chinese Year of Tourism are two quite different events.For example, the celebration of the Euro-Chinese Year of Tourism can bring significant financial, economic benefits and even has geopolitical implications, which is hard to say for the celebration of the European Year of Cultural Heritage.These two events will be celebrated in different ways, so I'm actually surprised by the proposal from the question to unite them, I don't see how these two events could be united.Obviously, the promotion of tourism can contribute to the celebration of the Euro-Chinese Year of Tourism, but I do not see how it would be the other way around.But I still support that part of the question that says that a way should be found for these two events to have synergies.

name: Karol Karski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Thank you for giving the floor. Of course, the matter is important. However, if we look at it in a very pragmatic way, then this initiative implemented by the European Commission should be assessed positively. Even those who pay attention to it from the point of view of human rights, see that the tourist exchange between Europe and China will bring the Chinese to come to Europe, learn about our standards of human rights protection, our standards of democracy. They will not only see their own country. They will see not only the solutions that are in other parts of the world, but the highest, best system that is being implemented here. On the other hand, the arrival of Europeans to China will mean that there will be not only people who do business with this country, who are interested in profit and leave, who are interested in contacts with the authorities, but also normal people whose presence there will also guarantee that that the Chinese authorities will have to somehow pay attention to what they are doing in their own territory. Maybe the impact will not be great, but a certain positive touch will also be an added value. So I would not be completely wrong with the question that has formed the basis of this debate. But at the same time, I would like to point out here the positive aspects of our debate today and this initiative that is being implemented in relations between the Union and China.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you to everyone who took part in this particular question. Can I emphasise on behalf of Commissioner Bieńkowska that these are two separate initiatives. One is about tourism, which is a decision that was made by President Juncker and Prime Minister Li on 12 July 2016 promoting the EU-China Tourism Year, and this decision was made one year before the decision to designate 2018 as the European Year of Cultural Heritage. The decision that established the European Year of Cultural Heritage for 2018 was taken by the Council and the Parliament on 17 May this year. So the tourism dimension came one year earlier, and it was set up for the purpose of trying to encourage additional tourists and travellers to come into the European Union. While I listened to contributors here today, I got the impression that the European Union budget was promoting Chinese tourism. It is actually promoting European tourism. It’s about bringing more people into the European Union, not the other way round, so the question of human rights does not arise. People have the freedom to travel, and we hope that visitors will come to the European Union and I am disappointed as some Members actually are trying to interpret this as some kind of an effort to say that Chinese travellers are not welcome. That is not the position of the European Union, and certainly not the position of the European Commission. In relation to the European Year of Cultural Heritage, this is a particular initiative for 2018 that requires all of the various processes that we know well to be implemented. In September 2017 a call for proposals for heritage cooperation projects was launched under the Creative Europe Programme, with EUR 5 million allocated and the deadline is actually next week on the 22 November 2017, so people still have time to make applications on this cultural heritage initiative. The European Year of Cultural Heritage is benefiting from many EU funding programmes which also support cultural heritage like Horizon 2020, COSME under the cultural tourism dimension, and Natura 2000. These are all programmes which will benefit from this particular fund. As with other European years, the year of cultural heritage will be implemented through a series of initiatives and events at European level. National, regional and local levels are involved. It has nothing to do with promoting tourism or cultural tourism with China, it’s about promoting cultural heritage in the European Union at local, regional and national level. So it is very much a ‘bottoms-up’ approach or at national level, the year has been managed by national coordinators who were appointed by all 28 Member States. The Commission is also being assisted by a committee which comprises 35 representative civil society organisations that are active in the field of heritage, culture and youth. I welcome this particular programme very much and I hope that people will actually apply for it, but it has nothing to do with Chinese-European relations. Finally, in relation to agriculture and the area of culture, the European Union and China are negotiating an agreement at the moment on geographical indications, which I am sure the House will welcome. Hopefully we will be able to reach agreement on this. This will promote European and Chinese culture around the issue of food and food heritage. I think that can only be beneficial for our rural areas. I am glad to have the opportunity, on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Bieńkowska, to clarify these particular issues for Members today.
